{{multiple issues| {{notability|Neologisms|date=July 2012}} {{original research |date=March 2012}} {{primary sources |date=March 2011}} {{essay-like |date=March 2011}}}} [[Image:DiVaD540.gif|thumb|A 540 crescent kick]]
In [[martial arts]] and tricking,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=NTjTAQAAQBAJ&pg=PT123&dq=double+leg+540+kick&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjSpuuwy9zVAhUMIMAKHRIjCaIQ6AEIMjAC#v=onepage&q=double+leg+540+kick&f=false|title=Knowledge - The Urban Skillz Dictionary|first=Sezai|last=Coban|date=4 August 2013|publisher=Sezai Coban|accessdate=16 August 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=yc52BgAAQBAJ&pg=PA227&dq=double+leg+540+kick&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjSpuuwy9zVAhUMIMAKHRIjCaIQ6AEILDAB#v=onepage&q=double+leg+540+kick&f=false|title=American Tricksters: Thoughts on the Shadow Side of a Culture's Psyche|first=William J.|last=Jackson|date=18 December 2014|publisher=Wipf and Stock Publishers|accessdate=16 August 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref> the '''540 kick''' (Chinese:旋風腳 (''Xuanfengjiao'')) (also known as '''inside turning kick''', '''jump inside kick''', and '''"hyper"''' '''tornado kick''') is a [[jump kick]] move.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/olympic_infographics_and_data/9466551/Interactive-graphic-How-to-perform-a-tornado-kick-in-Taekwondo.html|title=Interactive graphic: How to perform a tornado kick in Taekwondo|work=[[The Daily Telegraph|Telegraph]]|accessdate=31 January 2017}}</ref> It involves a rotation of approximately 540 degrees (although when performed correctly the performer has only done a spin of 360 degrees – not including whatever takeoff used).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XDDKml6q3c8C&pg=PA296&dq=540+kick&hl=en&sa=X&ei=na6xVM-YNsG0Uam0hNAI&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=540%20kick&f=false|title=World of sports indoor|publisher=|accessdate=11 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZNwDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA80&dq=Jump+inside+kick&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Xa-xVL2TKJbZatOXgtgI&ved=0CCYQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=Jump%20inside%20kick&f=false|title=Black Belt|publisher=Books.google.co.uk|accessdate=11 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UUwSBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA227&dq=540+kick&hl=en&sa=X&ei=BLexVPnOCMXwUoeigpgJ&ved=0CEUQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=540%20kick&f=false|title=American Tricksters|publisher=Books.google.co.uk|accessdate=11 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=FtIDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA30&dq=Tornado%20kick&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi98Lvo6OzRAhVDkJAKHSDmD6AQ6AEIGjAA#v=onepage&q=Tornado%20kick&f=false|title=Black Belt|first=Active Interest Media|last=Inc|date=1 May 1993|publisher=Active Interest Media, Inc.|accessdate=31 January 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Y9kDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA86&dq=Tornado%20kick&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi98Lvo6OzRAhVDkJAKHSDmD6AQ6AEIKTAD#v=onepage&q=Tornado%20kick&f=false|title=Black Belt|first=Active Interest Media|last=Inc|date=1 July 1998|publisher=Active Interest Media, Inc.|accessdate=31 January 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref>
It is practiced various disciplines including [[Taekwondo]], [[Tang Soo Do]], [[Wushu (sport)|Wushu]], [[Shaolin (martial arts)|Shaolin Quan]], [[Capoeira]] and some [[Karate]] styles but traditionally most associated with the Korean martial arts. However, the most prominent defining feature is that the same leg is used for taking off, kicking, and landing.The other leg is used to propel the performer into the air, and is then retracted before landing. Many martial arts tricksters choose this move as their first move to attempt.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Yc8DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT15&dq=JUMP+INSIDE+ROUNDHOUSE;&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ia-xVOeqNMHUat_ggeAK&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=JUMP%20INSIDE%20ROUNDHOUSE%3B&f=false|title=Black Belt|publisher=Books.google.co.uk|accessdate=11 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=stcDAAAAMBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=black%20belt%201991&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwij66PLpZ3SAhXmIcAKHeCtDwY4ChDoAQgxMAY#v=snippet&q=flying%20kicks&f=false|title=Black Belt|first=Active Interest Media|last=Inc|date=1 February 1991|publisher=Active Interest Media, Inc.|accessdate=20 February 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref>
This move has a history in ballet as well, where it is performed as an advanced variation of a 'barrel roll'. Principal male ballet dancers include the move in their variation (solo) as a crowd-pleasing feat of excellence. The move and a variation of it, the reverse 540, has been present in ballet for quite some time now, and is used commonly by dancers such as [[Daniil Simkin]], [[Tetsuya Kumakawa]] and Joseph Phillips. This move has been recently introduced into the world of [[professional wrestling]], where it is commonly referred to as a "jumping corkscrew roundhouse kick".
==Variations== Like most variations of martial arts kicks, the name of the kick is normally determined by the position of the foot, degree of rotation and positioning of the hips, and any additional kicks that may be added during the execution:
===Fake 540=== A jump turning kick that mimics the 540. The practitioner, already facing he target, jumps up to perform an inside crescent or roundhouse kick, and tucks the other to then land on the kicking foot. This motion does not share the full take off pattern of a true 540.
===540 Crescent=== This variation of the kick is typically found in wushu. The kick is executed as a [[Kick#Crescent kick|crescent kick]], meaning that the toes are pointed forewards with the hips facing the target. If aiming for a target, the target would be hit with the inside of the foot (from the heel to the big toe).
===540 Roundhouse=== This version rotates the hips about 90° more than a crescent before executing the kick. The kick is executed as a [[roundhouse kick]] meaning that a target would be hit with the top of the foot or ankle to avoid breaking the toes. It is also called a Bolley Kick by some in [[TaeKwonDo]], and was popularized in the mid-eighties by [[George Chung]] and [[Steven Ho (martial artist)|Steven Ho]] in open martial art competitions. In [[TaeKwonDo]], a tricking "540" kick refers to this 540 roundhouse, rather than the [[TaeKwonDo]] 540 hook kick.
===Reverse 540=== The take off of this is like a 1-over 360 kick. If back on your right foot, throw it forward counterclockwise, tuck it and push off with your right. Jump up and complete 360 with an outside, counterclockwise crescent kick and land on the same foot. Look at the reverse image of a 540 and you can see it.
===Lazyboy 540 (aka Playboy 540)=== Also referred to as simply a ''Lazyboy'', this version is identical to a typical 540 from a technical standpoint. The defining characteristic is that the hands are placed on the back or top of the head. This pose is to simulate the image of a person relaxing or lying down. While struck in the air, this variation is performed to show the ease in which they can perform the trick, demonstrating that they don't need the momentum of the arms to complete the trick, and/or to add style to the trick. This trick is also known as the ''Playboy 540'' for its extravagance and confident posture such of a playboy.
===Double leg 540=== This is performed with a take off from both legs and executed with an inside crescent kick.
===Sideswipe=== Though, the body mechanics/technique is different, the Sideswipe and 540 are categorized together because they both use the same leg to take off, kick, and land. This version is similar to a standard 540 kick, but the body is spinning parallel to the ground and can be performed almost inverted. After the non-kicking leg is thrown up in the take-off, the body is leaned back so it is spinning at least horizontally. This kick has less practical use due to the higher levels of agility required.
===540 Hook (c720)=== Also called a "Cheat 720" or a "540 Wheel," the 540 hook uses the same takeoff as mentioned previously. However, instead of using the jumping leg to kick, the performer spins around another 180 degrees and performs a hook kick or outside crescent kick with the other leg, depending on the position of the foot. This kick is one of the variations that actually spins a full 540°. A [[TaeKwonDo]] "540" refers to this kick.
===540 Gyro=== In this move, the user will execute a 540 crescent/roundhouse kick but instead of landing immediately on the kicking leg, the kicker will rotate an additional 360 degrees mid-air before landing. It is rather uncommon in the tricking community due to its difficulty, but is present in martial arts disciplines. It is most prevalent in [[Wushu (sport)|Wushu]].
===540 to Splits=== The traditional 540 can be landed into the splits by sending the kicking leg backwards after the kick as been executed and extending the other leg forward during the landing. Theoretically, almost every trick can be landed in the splits, however, landing some of the more advanced versions of tricks like this would require extra height in the jump, extra rotation of the body, and a very keen sense of timing and spatial awareness.
===Multi-Kick Variants=== Some variants of the 540 include multiple kicks being executed while in the air. Some of those variations are:
====Crescent 540/Feilong==== Not to be confused with the 540 crescent, a crescent 540 is where a crescent kick is thrown out with the first leg before the regular 540 kick is thrown with the other. Both of these kicks are executed mid-air. A variation of this is where the first crescent kick is thrown as a twisted front kick, followed by a round house kick. For this the hips must be rotated more before the kicks are thrown, allowing the feet to be turned towards the targets.
====Jacknife==== This is similar to a crescent 540 in that there are two kicks executed in sequence, however the 540 kick (either crescent or roundhouse) is thrown out first. Immediately following the first kick, the other leg comes around to execute a [[Reverse roundhouse kick|heel kick]] after rotating an additional 180 degrees. The mechanics to this variant are almost identical to a 540-wheel or cheat 720. Proper execution of this involves performing a roundhouse kick instead of an inside crescent kick, with the hips turned over and toes pointed. In doing so, after the first kick is completed, the kicker's hips and body are in a better position to spin around and snap out the hook.
====540 Triple==== This is the combination of a crescent 540 and a jacknife, essentially executing three separate kicks during the same motion. One with the landing leg and two with the other. The kicks and their execution are similar to those of a [[360 Crescent kick#720 kicks|720 triple]]. This move is commonly performed in [[TaeKwonDo]] demonstrations.
===Further reading=== * ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20070817130046/http://www.highperformancewushu.com/BookInfo.php Fundamentals of High Performance Wushu: Taolu Jumps and Spins]'' by Raymond Wu, {{ISBN|978-1-4303-1820-0}}. Step-by-step training book that describes how to do the kick, 360°, 540°, 720°, etc.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.flashmavi.com/wushu_whirlwind_kick_tornado_720_XFJ.shtml The chinese Tornado Kick - aka Whirlwindkick 360, 540 and 720] *[http://www.wushuwiki.org/Xuanfengjiao Wushuwiki Xuanfengjiao]
{{DEFAULTSORT:540 Kick}} [[Category:Kicks]] [[Category:Martial art techniques]] [[Category:Wushu (sport)]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox museum | name = Ajax Experience | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = Ajax_Experience.jpeg | caption = | alt = | map_type = Netherlands Amsterdam Central | map_caption = Location of the museum in Amsterdam | map_alt = | coordinates = {{coord|52.3661|4.8978|region:NL|display=inline,title}} | established = 24 September 2011 | dissolved = 1 August 2013 | location = [[Rembrandtplein]], entry at Utrechtsestraat 9
1017 DA Amsterdam | type = Sports Museum | collection = | visitors = | director = | president = | curator = Paul van den Boom | publictransit = | network = | website = [http://www.ajaxexperience.nl Official website]{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{nl icon}} }} The '''Ajax Experience''' was a [[museum]] dedicated to [[AFC Ajax]]' club history in [[Amsterdam]] in the [[Netherlands]]. The museum, located at the [[Rembrandtplein]], was opened on 24 September 2011 and closed within two years after a 9 million euro loss. == History == On 24 September 2011,{{cite web|url=http://pretwerk.nl/topnieuws/nieuwe-attractie-in-amsterdam-geopend-de-ajax-experience/7086|title=Nieuwe attractie in Amsterdam geopend: De Ajax Experience|author=Pretwerk|accessdate=8 November 2013}} Ajax Amsterdam opened the Ajax Experience as an attempt to bring the [[World of Ajax]] tour closer to [[Amsterdam-Centrum]]. Designed by [[Sid Lee]] and [[Gsmprjct°]], the Ajax Experience was an interactive experience which shared the philosophy of the club with the public, as well as bring the audience closer to the likes of [[Johan Cruijff]], [[Marco van Basten]] or [[Wesley Sneijder]]. Various national and international trophies that were won by the club over the years were on public display as well.{{cite web|url=http://afootballreport.com/post/15663048817/the-ajax-experience-x-sid-lee-architecture-aside|title=The Ajax Experience x Sid Lee Architecture|author=A Football Report|accessdate=8 November 2013}} With an estimated 3,5 million to 4,5 million fans in the Netherlands, and even more abroad, the Ajax Experience aimed to cater to the various fans who not only frequent the [[Amsterdam ArenA]] or [[Sportpark De Toekomst]], but also those who are visiting Amsterdam as a tourist destination who are not looking to deviate too far from the trusted central area near by frequented destinations such as [[Stopera]], [[Joods Historisch Museum]], Tunfun, or [[Natura Artis Magistra|Artis]].{{cite web|url=http://www.parool.nl/parool/nl/13/AJAX/article/detail/303402/2010/07/02/Ajax-krijgt-experience-center-in-Amsterdam.dhtml|title=Ajax krijgt 'experience center' in Amsterdam|author=Het Parool|accessdate=8 November 2013}} ==Location== Situated on the famed Rembrandtsplein in Amsterdam-Centrum in a former [[ABN-AMRO]] banking facility, the 1,400 m2 space proved to be optimal to provide the needed room to supply an interactive experience which featured cinematic match summaries, while showcasing the overall successes and big names associated with the club on the historic downtown square.{{cite web|url=http://www.parool.nl/parool/nl/13/AJAX/article/detail/2925053/2011/09/23/Ajax-Experience-opent-op-Rembrandtplein.dhtml|title=Ajax Experience opent op Rembrandtplein|author=Het Parool|accessdate=8 November 2013}} ==Dissolution== On 23 July 2013 it was announced that Ajax would discontinue the Ajax Experience, citing a loss in revenue as the cause for the discontinuation of the establishment.{{cite web|url=http://www.beurs.nl/nieuws/binnenland/3203889/ajax-stopt-met-verliesgevende-project-ajax-experience|title=Ajax stopt met verliesgevende project Ajax Experience|author=Beurs.NL|accessdate=8 November 2013}} The [[World of Ajax]] situated at the stadium would however continue to serve as a touristic function for the club, while the fanshop situated at the same location as the Experience remained open until 1 February 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraaf.nl/telesport/voetbal/ajax/21756118/__Ajax_stopt_met_Ajax_Experience__.html|title=Ajax stopt met Ajax Experience|author=De Telegraaf|accessdate=8 November 2013}} The club made a reported €9 Million loss over the course of two years through the museum, which resulted in its immediate shutdown only 2 years after its opening day.{{cite web|url=http://www.rtlnieuws.nl/economie/home/ajax-verliest-9-miljoen-euro-op-museum|title=Ajax verliest 9 miljoen euro op museum|author=RTL Z|accessdate=8 November 2013}} ==See also== *[[World of Ajax]] == References == {{reflist}} {{AFC Ajax}} == External links == * [http://www.projectcredits.com/p/54e657855bcb0/ajax-experience Ajax Experience on projectcredits.com] {{DEFAULTSORT:Ajax Experience}} [[Category:2011 establishments in the Netherlands]] [[Category:AFC Ajax facilities]] [[Category:Association football museums and halls of fame]] [[Category:Museums in Amsterdam]] [[Category:Defunct museums in the Netherlands]]

|num_staff = |num_volunteers= |budget = |website = [http://www.accusfia.us/] |remarks = }} The '''Automobile Competition Committee for the United States''' (ACCUS) is an [[umbrella organization]] of [[auto racing]] [[Sport governing body|sanctioning bodies]] in the [[United States]]. It is the official liaison of U.S. sanctioning bodies to the [[Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile]]. It was founded in 1955 to take over FIA representation when the [[American Automobile Association]] withdrew from racing and dissolved the [[AAA Contest Board]].{{cite journal|last=Capps |first=Don |author2=[[Cameron Argetsinger]] |title=Where Upon Our Scribe, Sherman, & Mr. Peabody Once Again Crank Up The Way-Back Machine for 1961... |journal=AtlasF1 |date=25 October 2000 |volume=6 |series=Rear View Mirror |issue=43 |url=http://atlasf1.autosport.com/2000/mal/mirror.html |accessdate=1 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yMmon9p8?url=http://atlasf1.autosport.com/2000/mal/mirror.html |archivedate=1 May 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }} ACCUS processes international competition licenses for drivers in the U.S. and provides [[Homologation (motorsport)|homologation]] and record keeping. ACCUS is also responsible for the inspection process and the issuance of FIA Historic Technical Passports (HTP) for competitors wishing to take part in International Historic events sanctioned by FIA worldwide. ==Member clubs== The member clubs are:{{cite web |url=http://www.accusfia.us/member_clubs.html |title=Member Clubs |publisher=ACCUS |accessdate=2018-08-23}} *[[IndyCar|Indy Racing League, LLC]] (INDYCAR) *[[International Motor Sports Association]] (IMSA) *[[National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing]] (NASCAR) {{ref|A|A}} *[[National Hot Rod Association]] (NHRA) *[[Sports Car Club of America]] (SCCA){{ref|A|A}} *[[United States Auto Club]] (USAC){{ref|A|A}} :{{note|A|A}} Founding member ==Former member clubs== *[[Champ Car|Championship Auto Racing Teams]] (CART/Champ Car) *[[Grand American Road Racing Association]] (Grand-Am) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.accusfia.us/ Official site] {{Sports governing bodies of the United States}} [[Category:Auto racing organizations in the United States]] [[Category:National sporting authorities of the FIA]] [[Category:Companies based in Denver]] {{motorsport-stub}} {{US-sport-stub}}

[[Charlotte, North Carolina]] 28202 | coordinates = {{Coord|35.227988|-80.849011|type:landmark_region:US-NC|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = September 14, 2012{{cite news|title=Knights Break Ground on Stadium to Bring Baseball Back to Charlotte |first=April |last=Bethea |url=http://www.charlotteobserver.com/2012/09/14/3528990/groundbreaking-for-knights-stadium.html |newspaper=[[The Charlotte Observer]] |date=September 14, 2012 |accessdate=September 17, 2012 |page=1B |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121124150317/http://www.charlotteobserver.com/2012/09/14/3528990/groundbreaking-for-knights-stadium.html |archivedate=November 24, 2012 |df= }} | built = | |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407082729/http://www.wccbcharlotte.com/news/top-stories/Annual-Media-Softball-Game-Kicks-off-BBT-Park-251725821.html |archivedate=April 7, 2014 |df= }} | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Mecklenburg County, North Carolina|Mecklenburg County]] | operator = [[Charlotte Knights|Knights Baseball, LLC]] | surface = Grass | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]54 million | architect = Odell Associates, Inc. in association with BallparkDesignAssociates{{cite web |title=Charlotte Knights Uptown Baseball Stadium|url=http://www.odell.com/portfolio/category/play/?project=charlotte-knights-uptown-baseball-stadium|publisher=Odell Associates, Inc.|accessdate=July 6, 2012}} | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = Smith Seckman Reid, Inc.{{cite web |title=BB&T Park|url=http://www.ssr-inc.com/projects/bbt-park/|publisher=Smith Seckman Reid, Inc.|accessdate=April 23, 2014}} | general_contractor = Barton Malow/R. J. Leeper/Rodgers | main_contractors = | capacity = 10,200{{cite news |title=Hundreds Turn Out at New BB&T Ballpark to Buy Knights Single-Game Tickets|first=Joe|last=DePriest|url=http://www.charlotteobserver.com/2014/03/08/4750954/hundreds-turn-out-at-new-bbt-ballpark.html#.Uz43Wvn6MrU|newspaper=[[The Charlotte Observer]]|date=March 8, 2014|accessdate=April 3, 2014}} | dimensions = '''Left field''': {{convert|330|ft|m}}
'''Center field''':{{convert|400|ft|m}}
'''Right Field''':{{convert|315|ft|m}} | tenants = [[Charlotte Knights]] ([[International League|IL]]) (2014–present) }} '''BB&T Ballpark''' is a [[baseball]] stadium in [[Charlotte, North Carolina]].{{cite news|title=BB&T, Knights Agree on Uptown Ballpark Rights |first=Steve |last=Lyttle |url=http://www.charlotteobserver.com/2012/04/23/3192838/bbt-knights-agree-on-uptown-ballpark.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130119004504/http://www.charlotteobserver.com/2012/04/23/3192838/bbt-knights-agree-on-uptown-ballpark.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=January 19, 2013 |newspaper=[[The Charlotte Observer]] |date=April 23, 2012 |accessdate=April 23, 2012 }} The [[Charlotte center city|Uptown]]-area stadium hosts the [[Charlotte Knights]], a [[Triple-A (baseball)|Triple-A]] [[Minor League Baseball]] team in the [[International League]]. It is also the third sports building to be built in Uptown, after [[Bank of America Stadium]] (home of the NFL's [[Carolina Panthers]]) and [[Spectrum Center (arena)|Spectrum Center]] (home of the NBA's [[Charlotte Hornets]]). ==History== An Uptown stadium for the Knights had been a long-running saga in Charlotte, occasionally the subject of contentious debate. Since the dawn of the new millennium, the Knights had consistently had the worst attendance in the [[International League]]. Their stadium at the time, [[Knights Stadium]], was located in [[Fort Mill, South Carolina]], 30 minutes south of Uptown Charlotte. Many fans were unwilling to brave the traffic on [[Interstate 77]] to get there. The project had been repeatedly blocked by Jerry Reese, a Charlotte lawyer who claimed the land swap was illegal.{{cite news|title=Attorneys Argue Baseball Land Swap Lawsuit In Union County |url=http://www.wsoctv.com/news/16090342/detail.html |work=[[WSOC-TV|WSOC]] |location=Charlotte |date=April 30, 2008 |accessdate=April 30, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080501172012/http://www.wsoctv.com/news/16090342/detail.html |archivedate=May 1, 2008 |df= }} Reese had ambitions to move a [[Major League Baseball]] team to Charlotte and viewed a Triple-A sized stadium for the Knights as a detriment.{{cite news |title=A Major League Income Shortfall|first=Erik|last=Spanberg|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/charlotte/stories/2006/02/06/story1.html|newspaper=[[American City Business Journals|Charlotte Business Journal]]|date=February 6, 2006|accessdate=February 6, 2006}} In August 2006 the stadium became the source of more debate, as [[Mecklenburg County, North Carolina|Mecklenburg County]] commission chairman Parks Helms said he would stall an arts project until the [[City Council of Charlotte, North Carolina|Charlotte City Council]] looked at a proposal he backed to bring baseball to Uptown.{{cite news |title=Proposal Links New Stadium, Arts Tax, Helms' Plan Has Some Backing on Board, and Sharp Disagreement|first1=Carrie|last1=Levine|first2=Steven|last2=Brown|first3=Greg|last3=LaCour|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_action=list&p_topdoc=11|newspaper=[[The Charlotte Observer]]|date=August 25, 2006|accessdate=April 22, 2014|page=1A}} Furthermore, it could expand the [[Atlantic Coast Conference]]'s plans to return the [[Atlantic Coast Conference Baseball Tournament]] to Charlotte. The ACC tournament had been held at Knights Stadium until the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA's]] ban on South Carolina having predetermined championships took effect because of [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People|NAACP]] pressure in relation to the boycott of the state by the organization. Multiple new [[mid-rise]] hotels are expected to open in the area around the new stadium, along with restaurants and retail.{{cite news |title=Retail, Office Towers, Hotels Top Uptown Charlotte's To-Do List|first=Erik|last=Spanberg|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/charlotte/blog/queen_city_agenda/2014/02/retail-office-towers-hotels-top-uptown-charlottes.html?page=all|newspaper=[[American City Business Journals|Charlotte Business Journal]]|date=February 4, 2014|accessdate=April 22, 2014}} The first event held at the ballpark was a media softball game, which took place on March 22, 2014. The first Knights game took place on April 11, 2014.{{cite news|title=Charlotte Knights Announce Date for First Uptown Game at BB&T Ballpark |first=Ben |last=Weinrib |url=http://www.charlotteobserver.com/2013/07/31/4204751/knights-announce-date-for-first.html |newspaper=[[The Charlotte Observer]] |date=July 31, 2013 |accessdate=August 27, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407065251/http://www.charlotteobserver.com/2013/07/31/4204751/knights-announce-date-for-first.html |archivedate=April 7, 2014 |df= }} The stadium hosted the 2016 [[Triple-A All-Star Game]] in which the [[International League]] All-Stars defeated the [[Pacific Coast League]] All-Stars, 4–2.{{Cite web|url=http://www.triple-abaseball.com/ASGSummaries6.jsp|title=Triple-A All-Star Game Results (2013–2017)|publisher=Triple-A Baseball|accessdate=July 7, 2017}} On January 31, 2018, Charlotte Knights Chief Operating Officer Dan Rajkowski announced that the Knights will host a total of six college baseball games this season during the [https://www.sunbeltrentals.com/about/ Sunbelt Rentals Collegiate Baseball Series]. This is the most in BB&T Ballpark history. ==Naming rights== On April 23, 2012, it was announced that [[BB&T]] acquired the naming rights for the new ballpark. The terms of the deal were undisclosed and the ballpark will be officially referred to as BB&T Ballpark indefinitely. ==Features== File:BB&T Ballpark.jpg|The stadium before a game File:BB&T Ballpark scoreboard.jpg|The left-field scoreboard File:BB&T Ballpark Skyline.jpg|The view from left field, with the Charlotte skyline The stadium features a two-level club with skyline views as well as a VIP, climate-controlled club with full service bar.{{cite web |title=Club Seats|url=http://charlotteknightsatuptown.com/partnership-opportunities/hospitality-options/item/37-club-seats|publisher=Charlotte Knights at Uptown|accessdate=July 6, 2012}} In total, there are 975 club seats and 22 luxury suites at the ballpark.{{cite news |title=BB&T Ballpark Is Reshaping Charlotte Knights Franchise|first=Erik|last=Spanburg|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/charlotte/print-edition/2013/07/05/bbt-ballpark-is-reshaping-franchise.html?page=all|newspaper=[[American City Business Journals|Charlotte Business Journal]]|date=July 5, 2013|accessdate=September 7, 2013}} It is thought to be slightly friendlier to hitters than typical minor-league parks. Knights general manager Scotty Smith said that due to the limited lot size, the foul lines are a few feet shorter than minor-league guidelines. ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|BB&T Ballpark (Charlotte)}} *[http://www.milb.com/content/page.jsp?ymd=20140422&content_id=73020552&sid=t494&vkey=team1 Official website] {{International League baseball venue navbox}} {{Charlotte sports venues}} {{DEFAULTSORT:BBandT Ballpark (Charlotte)}} [[Category:Sports venues in Charlotte, North Carolina]] [[Category:Baseball venues in North Carolina]] [[Category:Charlotte Knights]] [[Category:2014 establishments in North Carolina]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2014]]

revision.text:
{{update|date=November 2010}} '''Dubai Golf City''' is a mixed-use $1.8 billion project covering an area of {{convert|55000000|sqft}}. The project was intended for completion in [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]] in late 2009, but has been on hold with only one golf course partly completed. This golf course is being maintained but is not yet operational. The development, when completed, will feature [[golf course]]s, a golf academy and [[Convention (meeting)|convention centre]]s. It is one of the largest projects at [[Dubailand]].
==Attractions== *Five themed golf courses *Golf Academy *Hotel, Convention Centre *6-star resort and spa *Themed golf villages *Mansion and villas
==See also== *[[Dubai Sports City]]
==References== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090330215739/http://dubaigolfcity.org/ Official website]
{{Developments in Dubai}} {{coord|25.006595|55.240288|display=t|type:landmark}}

[[Dushanbe]], [[Tajikistan]] |capacity = |chairman = |manager = |league = |season = [[2008 Tajik League|2008]] |position = 6th }} '''Dynamo Dushanbe''' is football club based in [[Dushanbe]] in [[Tajikistan]]. ==History== The club was founded in 1937 under the name "Dinamo Stalinabad", before changing its name to "Dynamo Dushanbe" in 1971. In 2007, Dynamo Dushanbe merged with [[Oriyono Dushanbe]], keeping their name.{{cite web|title=Tajikistan 2007|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablest/taji07.html|publisher=RSSSF|accessdate=14 October 2015}} ===Domestic history=== {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#efefef;" ! rowspan="2" | Season ! colspan="9" | League ! rowspan="2" | [[Tajik Cup]] ! colspan="2" | Top goalscorer ! rowspan="2" | Manager |- ! {{infobox venue | name = Estadi Nacional | nickname = | image = | fullname = Estadi Nacional d'Andorra | former_names = | location = [[Andorra la Vella]], [[Andorra]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = 2013 | built = | opened = 2014 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = Artificial turf | scoreboard = | estimated_cost = | suites = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 3,306 | record_attendance = 3,193
[[Andorra national football team|Andorra]] v [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]]
(7 October 2017)[https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2017/10/07/europe/wc-qualifying-europe/andorra/portugal/2116236/ Andorra v Portugal boxscore]; Soccerway.com | executive_suites = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = [[Andorra national football team]]
[[Andorra national rugby union team]] }} The '''Estadi Nacional''' is a stadium located in [[Andorra la Vella]]. It is the [[national stadium]] of [[Andorra]], and is used for [[association football]] and [[rugby union]]. It has a capacity of 3,306, and the pitch is made of [[artificial turf]].[http://www.govern.ad/esports/item/5579-la-gespa-de-l-estadi-nacional-supera-el-test-independent-per-obtenir-la-validacio-de-la-fifa La gespa de l’Estadi Nacional supera el test independent per obtenir la validació de la FIFA] ==History== The stadium was built at the former ground of the Camp d'Esports del M.I. Consell General. Construction started in 2013 and finished in 2014.[https://www.bopa.ad/bopa/documents/026051.pdf Butlletí Oficial del Principat d'Andorra] The stadium is the home of the [[Andorra national football team]] and the [[Andorra national rugby union team]]. The first official match was a 1–2 defeat to [[Wales national football team|Wales]] valid for the [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying Group B]], played on 9 September 2014, after the 3G artificial pitch passed UEFA inspection a week before the match.[https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29042198 Euro 2016: Wales qualifier in Andorra will not be moved] In August 2015, the National Government and [[FC Andorra]] acorded the club would play in the Estadi Nacional the two first months of the 2015–16 season, until the works in the Camp de la Borda Mateu finish.{{cite web|url=http://www.bondia.ad/esports/lfc-andorra-jugara-lestadi-nacional-els-dos-primers-mesos|language=Catalan|date=4 August 2015|title=L’FC Andorra jugarà a l’Estadi Nacional els dos primers mesos|publisher=Bon Dia}}{{cite web|url=http://www.andorradifusio.ad/esports/acord-entre-el-govern-i-lfc-andorra-per-jugar-a-lestadi-nacional|publisher=Andorra Difusió|language=Catalan|date=4 August 2015|title=Acord entre el Govern i l'FC Andorra per jugar a l'Estadi Nacional}} ==Attendances to official games== {{Updated|19 November 2018}} ===Football games=== {|class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:right" |- ! Season !width=65|{{Tooltip|Total|Total season attendance}} !width=55|{{Tooltip|High|Highest season attendance}} !width=55|{{Tooltip|Low|Lowest season attendance}} !width=55|{{Tooltip|Average|Average season attendance}} |- | align=left|[[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying Group B|Euro 2016]] || 11,778 || 3,150 || 1,054 || '''2,354''' |- | align=left|[[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Group B|2018 World Cup]] || 10,484 || 3,193 || 1,115 || '''2,097''' |- | align=left|[[2018–19 UEFA Nations League D|2018–19 Nations League]] || 3,567 || 1,311 || 1,021 || '''1,189''' |- |} Source[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/andorra/andorra/88/matches/ Soccerway][http://www.worldfootball.net/venues/estadi-nacional-andorra-la-vella/ Worldfootball.net] ===Rugby games=== {|class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:right" |- ! Season !width=65|{{Tooltip|Total|Total season attendance}} !width=55|{{Tooltip|High|Highest season attendance}} !width=55|{{Tooltip|Low|Lowest season attendance}} !width=55|{{Tooltip|Average|Average season attendance}} |- | align=left|[[2014–16 European Nations Cup Second Division|2014–16 European Nations Cup]] || 1,300 || 500 || 300 || '''433''' |- | align=left|[[2016–17 Rugby Europe Conference|2016–17 Rugby Europe Conference]] || 1,400 || 1,000 || 400 || '''700''' |- | align=left|[[2017–18 Rugby Europe Conference|2017–18 Rugby Europe Conference]] || 1,100 || 600 || 500 || '''550''' |- | align=left|[[2018–19 Rugby Europe Conference|2018–19 Rugby Europe Conference]] || 400 || 400 || 400 || '''400''' |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://eu-football.info/_venue.php?id=2346 Estadi Nacional at EU-Football.info] {{Andorra national football team}} {{Andorra la Vella}} {{coord|42.5046|N|1.5175|E|source:wikidata|display=title}} [[Category:Football venues in Andorra]] [[Category:Sports in Andorra la Vella]] [[Category:National stadiums|Andorra]] [[Category:2014 establishments in Andorra]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2014]]

{{Infobox football biography | name = Fernando Astengo | image = | fullname = Fernando Enrique Astengo Sánchez | height = {{height|m=1.77}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1960|1|8|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Santiago (Chile)|Santiago]], [[Chile]] | position = [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|Centre back]] | youthyears1 = 1973–1977 | youthclubs1 = [[Unión Española]] | years1 = 1978–1985 | years2 = 1979 | years3 = 1986 | years4 = 1987–1990 | years5 = 1993–1998 | years6 = 1995 | clubs1 = [[Unión Española]] | clubs2 = → [[Rangers de Talca|Rangers]] (loan) | clubs3 = [[Colo-Colo]] | clubs4 = [[Grêmio Foot-Ball Porto Alegrense|Grêmio]] | clubs5 = [[Unión Española]] | clubs6 = → [[Audax Italiano]] (loan) | caps1 = | goals1 = | caps2 = | goals2 = | caps3 = | goals3 = | caps4 = | goals4 = | caps5 = | goals5 = | caps6 = | goals6 = | nationalyears1 = 1986–1989 | nationalteam1 = [[Chile national football team|Chile]] | nationalcaps1 = 18 | nationalgoals1 = 3 | manageryears1 = 2008 | manageryears2 = 2013 | managerclubs1 = [[Colo-Colo]] | managerclubs2 = [[Deportes Temuco]] }}
'''Fernando Enrique Astengo Sánchez''' (born 8 January 1960) is a former [[Association football|footballer]] and current manager.
During his years as footballer he played as [[centre back]], position which was well considered after being featured in [[:es:Equipo Ideal de América|1988's America Ideal Team]]. Despite of his success, in 1989, Astengo was involved in [[El Maracanazo (1990 FIFA World Cup qualification)|Chilean national team scandal at Maracanã]], which alongside keeper [[Roberto Rojas]] and his coach [[:Orlando Aravena]] received a three-year ban by the [[FIFA]].
Upon retiring as a footballer he became a manager starting to work with [[Colo-Colo]] lower divisions, later having a brief spell as first-team caretaker coach in 2008, replacing [[Claudio Borghi]]. However, he left the [[Estadio Monumental David Arellano|Pedreros]]–based team and then had short periods at [[Unión San Felipe]] youth ranks in 2009,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cooperativa.cl/fernando-astengo-se-hara-cargo-de-las-divisiones-inferiores-de-union-san-felipe/prontus_nots/2009-09-29/205254.html |title=Fernando Astengo se hará cargo de las divisiones inferiores de Unión San Felipe |publisher=[[La Tercera]] |date=29 September 2009}}</ref> and [[Deportes Temuco]] in 2013.

[[File:JRDragsterrace.JPG|thumb|Junior Dragsters]] The '''Junior Dragster''' is a scaled-down version of the [[top fuel]] [[drag racing|dragster]]. Also known as the '''Jr dragster''', it reaches speeds of up to 85 mph. The cars were developed in New Zealand in 1988, with classes developed by the New Zealand Hot Rod Association <ref>New Zealand Hot Rod Magazine, August 1988</ref>. The NHRA began sanctioning the class in 1991, with the JDRL (Junior Drag Racing League).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jrdragster.nhra.com/ |title=NHRA Summit Racing Jr. Drag Racing League |publisher=NHRA |date= |accessdate=2013-12-03}}</ref> The JDRL is a division of the NHRA, which consists of two different dragster classes, traditional Jr. Dragster having a wheelbase between 90-150 inches and a single-cylinder, five brake horsepower [[Briggs & Stratton]] engine, and the larger Jr. Comp dragster being 150-190 inches in [[wheelbase]] and using a motorcycle or [[personal watercraft]] engine. Junior drag racers may choose to participate in programs run by the [[NHRA]], [[International Hot Rod Association|IHRA]], or at an unsanctioned facility. Drivers may be male or female and must be at least five years of age to test, and six years to compete, and be no older than 20 years on December 31 of the competition year (a driver who turns 18 on January 2 is permitted to race in the class until December 31 of the year in question). [[File:JRDRAG.jpg|thumb|Back View of a Jr Dragster]]
The track is 1/8 of a mile, and depending on class, is contested as a [[E.T. bracket race|bracket race]] or a heads-up start on a 5-tenths sportsman tree. Racers E.T (Elapsed Time) is determined by age. Drivers age 5 can only test in single-car passes, and can go no faster than 20.00 seconds. Drivers age 6-7 can go no faster than 13.90 (and must start heads-up), and can officially compete in full competition. Drivers age 5-7 must use a crate engine from Briggs & Stratton with a [[slide valve]] to reduce power. Drivers age 8-9 can go no faster than 11.90, 10- to 12-year-olds are limited to 8.90 and 13- to 17-year-olds can go up to 7.90 at 85 mph. Drivers 14-20 can race in Jr. Comp, where racers are limited to 6.900 at 109.99 MPH. Drivers who are 9 as of January 1 can participate in either the 8-9 or 10-12 category once they turn 10 during the year, and drivers who are 12 as of January 1 can participate in the 10-12 or 13-17 category once they turn 13 during the year. Drivers who turn 14 may run in Jr. Comp. A driver who turns 18 during the year may stay in Jr. Dragster before jumping to either the adult classes or Jr. Comp. [[File:JRdrag.jpg|thumb|The gap between a slower car and a faster car in a bracket race]]
Jr.Dragsters also compete in a different racing class called 'Outlaw'. This class is run to the 330 ft cone of the racing surface. The class runs heads-up on a 4-tenths pro tree. Usually this class is a qualified field, so the teams have to give it all they can just to make the field. While different series rules vary, the main principle is the same. The different series restrict engine combinations and weight packages so that the cars do not exceed the 4.10 time NHRA says is the fastest junior dragsters can run to the 330 ft. legally.
[[File:JRIRONMAN.jpg|thumb|Winning the same trophy as the Pro's.]] Racers compete almost every weekend, running in points series at their home tracks, or in various specialty events with big prizes. During the course of the year, racers could also attend various division events, or Nationals. In the NHRA, racers choose between attending the [[NHRA Conference Finals|Eastern]], and the Western Conference Finals. In the UK there are over thirty racers and still growing. Though Bracket racing is still the main factor of Jr. drag racing, varieties of heads up racing are also a growing part of this sport. The next step up for Jr. Dragster is Jr. Comp, and then moving into the full size cars.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://jrdragster.nhra.com NHRA Junior Dragster Racing League] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100408111659/http://ihra.com/juniors/ IHRA Junior Dragsters] * [http://www.nhra.com NHRA Official website] * [http://www.ihra.com IHRA Official website] * [https://secure.nhra.powerade.com/contest/podcast.asp Official NHRA Drag Racing Podcasts]{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [http://www.dragracecentral.com/ Drag Race Central] The Latest NHRA News and Analysis * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140201221152/http://juniordragsterdreams.com/] First and only young people's novel about junior drag racing

{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2017}} The following are nicknames throughout the history of the [[National Football League]] (NFL).
== Teams and units == Nicknames for entire teams, or whole offensive or defensive units. * '''Ain'ts''':<ref name=Aints>{{cite news|last1=Bishop|first1=Greg|title=Beneath Brown Bags, Saints Had Loyal Fans|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/05/sports/football/05bag.html?_r=0|accessdate=May 25, 2016|work=The New York Times|date=February 4, 2010}}</ref> Nickname given to the [[New Orleans Saints]] after their [[1980 NFL season|1980 season]] of 14 consecutive losses. The name persisted somewhat as, although they would later qualify for the playoffs several times since then, they did not win a playoff game until their defeat of the defending Super Bowl champion [[St. Louis Rams|Rams]] in the Wild Card round of the [[2000–01 NFL playoffs|2000–01 playoffs]]. *'''[[America's Team]]''':<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0000C8AO2/|title=NFL Films: The Dallas Cowboys|accessdate=2007-01-18}}</ref> Nickname given to the Dallas Cowboys for having a large number of fans outside its immediate local area. (The term itself is likely derived from the title of the team's 1978 [[highlight film]].) * '''Big Blue''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsmedia101.com/newyorkgiants/2012/07/08/a-look-back-at-the-many-new-york-giants-handles-aliases-and-nicknames/|title=A look back at the many New York Giant handles, aliases, and nicknames|accessdate=2015-03-17|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402134945/http://www.sportsmedia101.com/newyorkgiants/2012/07/08/a-look-back-at-the-many-new-york-giants-handles-aliases-and-nicknames/|archivedate=April 2, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> An abridged version of the [[New York Giants]] nickname [[Big Blue Wrecking Crew]] *'''[[Big Blue Wrecking Crew]]''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsecyclopedia.com/nfl/nyg/nygiants.html|title=Sports E-Cyclopedia History of the NY Giants|accessdate=2007-01-18}}</ref> Name of the [[New York Giants]] [[defensive team]] during the 1980s and into the early 1990s. This defense is considered one of the greatest of all time, and is perhaps the greatest [[3–4 defense]] in NFL history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/431194-the-best-nfl-defensive-unit-nicknames#page/11 |title=The Best NFL Defensive Unit Nicknames |publisher=Bleacher Report |date=2010-08-07 |accessdate=2012-10-04}}</ref> * '''Bills West''':<ref name="roth">Roth, Leo. [https://www.usatoday.com/sports/nfl/stories/2001-10-23-bills-chargers.htm Bills East vs. Bills West]. [[Rochester Democrat and Chronicle]]. 23 October 2001.</ref><ref name="donbanks">[[Don Banks|Banks, Don]]. [http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/inside_game/don_banks/news/2001/10/19/banks_insider/ AFC is where all the action is lately]. SI.com. 19 October 2001.</ref> The [[2001 San Diego Chargers season|2001 San Diego Chargers]], so named because of the signing of the Buffalo Bills' former general manager, [[John Butler (American football general manager)|John Butler]], along with several Buffalo Bills players, including quarterback [[Doug Flutie]]. * '''Blitzburgh''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/teams/story/PIT/4465761 |title=Steelers' D making a name for itself |accessdate=2007-01-18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051101025225/http://www.nfl.com/teams/story/PIT/4465761 |archivedate=November 1, 2005 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Name of the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] defensive unit since the mid-1990s and their tendency to relentlessly attack opposing quarterbacks. * '''The Blue Wave''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/news/article/NFL-Beat-Rhodes-Warriors-need-a-nickname-1125071.php |title=NFL Beat: Rhodes' Warriors need a nickname|accessdate=2018-01-24}}</ref> Name of the [[Seattle Seahawks]] teams of the 1980's which included Hall of Famers [[Steve Largent]] and [[Kenny Easley]]. Quarterbacked by [[Dave Krieg]] and coached by [[Chuck Knox]]. The expansion franchise started to gain momentum and go on a roll. *'''[[Bruise Brothers (San Diego Chargers)|Bruise Brothers]]''':<ref>{{cite news |title=No. 16: Chargers' best draft class | date=March 28, 2009 |work=ESPN.com |url=http://insider.espn.go.com/nfl/insider/news/story?id=4017589 |accessdate=March 7, 2013 |quote=The 2001 class was good, but the 1975 class ranks the best. San Diego had four of the first 33 picks in the draft, and the Chargers selected three defensive linemen that would form the nucleus of "The Bruise Brothers" and once formed three-fourths of the AFC Pro Bowl defensive line.}}{{subscription required}}</ref> San Diego Chargers defensive line in the 1970s and 1980s. * '''Bull Elephant backfield''':<ref>{{cite news |url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C03E7DF123BF93AA2575AC0A9679C8B63|title= Tank Younger, 73, First Star From Black College to Play in N.F.L., Dies|accessdate=2008-07-25 |last= Goldstein|first= Richard|date= 2001-09-19|work= [[New York Times]]|publisher=}}</ref> running backs of the 1950s Rams: [[Dick Hoerner]], [[Paul "Tank" Younger]], and [[Dan Towler|"Deacon" Dan Towler]]. * '''Bulls on Parade''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.houstontexans.com/2011/12/04/bulls-on-parade-a-nickname-is-born/ |title=Houston Texans Blog |accessdate=2011-12-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111208002640/http://blog.houstontexans.com/2011/12/04/bulls-on-parade-a-nickname-is-born/ |archivedate=2011-12-08 |df= }}</ref> Refers to the [[Houston Texans]] defense, starting in the 2011 season (but is still a nickname for the Texans). After the hiring of [[Wade Phillips]], the defense went from almost last ranked in the NFL to ranked second at the end of the 2011 season, winning the [[AFC South]] for the first time and reaching the post-season for the first time in franchise history. The name is taken from the [[Rage Against The Machine]] song of the same name. * '''Bungles''':<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blog.washingtonpost.com/redskinsinsider/2006/08/cincinnati_bungles.html|title=Cincinnati Bungles|accessdate=2007-11-01|author=Jason La Canfora|work=Washington Post}}</ref> Name referring to the [[Cincinnati Bengals]] teams of the 1990s and 2000s, whose string of losing seasons with records 8–8 or worse spanned 14 consecutive years in addition to numerous draft busts. Name also used for any failing Cincinnati Bengals team thereafter. * '''Cardiac Cardinals (Cards)''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.angelfire.com/fl/TheCard/chron/chron20.html|title=Cardinal Chronicle XX|accessdate=2007-01-18}}</ref> the [[St. Louis Cardinals (NFL)|St. Louis Cardinals]] [[NFC East]] championship teams of [[1974 NFL season|1974]] (10–4) and [[1975 NFL season|'75]] (11–3). Noted for their come-from-behind wins under their head coach, [[Don Coryell]]. The name was resurrected for the [[1998 NFL season|1998]] team that upset [[Dallas Cowboys|Dallas]] in the wild card game.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.laprensa-sandiego.org/archieve/december31/playoffs.htm|title=NFL Playoffs Begin with Wild Card Weekend|accessdate=2007-01-18}}</ref> *'''[[Cardiac Cats]]''': nickname originally given to the [[2003 Carolina Panthers season|2003 Carolina Panthers]] and later to the Detroit Lions of the 2010s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/videos/detroit-lions/09000d5d822cd2c3/Cardiac-cats-strike-again|title=Cardiac Cats strike again|accessdate=2017-10-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nflshop.com/catalog/product/Reebok_Detroit_Lions_Cardiac_Cats_T-Shirt|title=Reebok Detroit Lions Cardiac Cats T-shirt|accessdate=2017-10-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freep.com/story/sports/nfl/lions/2016/12/05/detroit-lions-fourth-quarter-comebacks/94973218/|title=No Lions comeback this time: Cardiac Cats rest easy|accessdate=2017-10-14}}</ref> * '''Cardiac Jags''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://football.about.com/od/teamsjaguars/a/aa102204.htm|title=Leftwich, Cardiac Jags Stun Kansas City|accessdate=2007-12-17}}</ref> the [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] earned this nickname because of making several comeback wins and/or winning nail-biters. * '''Da Bears''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dabearsblog.com|title=Da Bears Fan Blog|accessdate=2007-01-18}}</ref> Slang nickname given to the [[Chicago Bears]] made popular by the [[Bill Swerski's Superfans]] sketches of the early 1990s on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''. Sometimes used to retroactively refer to the [[1985 Chicago Bears season|1985 Bears]]. * '''The Deadskins''': Given to the [[Washington Redskins]] squads under [[Daniel Snyder]] ownership for the team's poor performances, particularly during the 2000s. * '''Dirty Birds''':<ref name="sportsecyclopedia.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsecyclopedia.com/nfl/atlanta/falcons.html|title=Sports E-Cyclopedia History of the Atlanta Falcons|accessdate=2007-01-18}}</ref> The [[1998 NFL season|1998]] [[Atlanta Falcons]] (but is still a nickname for the Falcons). The name originates from an end zone dance started by [[Jamal Anderson]] that was adopted by all the players upon scoring. * '''The Dream Team''': In the 2011 offseason, the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] signed many notable free agents including [[Nnamdi Asomugha]], [[Jason Babin]], [[Evan Mathis]], [[Dominique Rodgers-Cromartie]] (acquired in a trade), and [[Vince Young]]. Young declared the Eagles to be a "Dream Team." The Eagles finish 8-8 in [[2011 Philadelphia Eagles season|2011]] and 4-12 in [[2012 Philadelphia Eagles season|2012]], with longtime head coach [[Andy Reid]] getting fired after the 2012 season. *'''[[Doomsday Defense]]''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsecyclopedia.com/nfl/dallas/cowboys.html|title=Sports E-Cyclopedia History of the Dallas Cowboys|accessdate=2007-01-18}}</ref> The 1970s [[Dallas Cowboys]] [[defensive team]]. Doomsday I, the unit that led the Cowboys to victory in [[Super Bowl VI]], was anchored by future [[Pro Football Hall of Fame]] members [[Herb Adderley]], [[Bob Lilly]], and [[Mel Renfro]], while Doomsday II, which spearheaded the drive to the title in [[Super Bowl XII]], featured Hall of Famer [[Randy White (American football)|Randy White]] and fellow defensive linemen [[Harvey Martin]] and [[Ed Jones (American football)|Ed "Too Tall" Jones]]. * '''Electric Company''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.buffalobills.com/history/November.jsp |title=November in Buffalo Bills History |accessdate=2007-01-18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061206142908/http://www.buffalobills.com/history/November.jsp |archivedate=December 6, 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The 1970s [[Buffalo Bills]] [[offensive line]]. They were given that name because they "turned on the 'Juice'" by paving the way for star halfback [[O.J. Simpson]], who was nicknamed "Juice", because a common nickname for [[orange juice]] is also O.J. * '''Evil Empire''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/20813246/|title=Pats embrace image as new Evil Empire|date=2007-09-17|publisher=MSNBCj|accessdate=2008-01-20|work=Mike Celizic}}</ref> Name associating the New England Patriots dynasty of the 2000s. Coach Bill Bellichick was deemed "evil" after the [[2007 National Football League videotaping controversy|Spygate]] scandal<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.aol.com/fanhouse/2007/11/06/don-shula-on-patriots-the-spygate-thing-has-diminished-what-th/12|title=Don Shula on Patriots: 'the Spygate Thing Has Diminished What They've Accomplished'|date=2007-11-06|publisher=AOL Sports|accessdate=2008-01-29|work=Michael David Smith}}</ref> and the term is a play on Belichick's frequent use of hooded sweatshirts on the sideline, making him resemble the [[Emperor Palpatine]] character from the ''[[Star Wars]]'' motion picture series. *'''[[Fearsome Foursome (football)|Fearsome Foursome]]''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsecyclopedia.com/nfl/larams/larams.html|title=Sports E-Cyclopedia History of the LA Rams|accessdate=2007-01-18}}</ref> The 1960s [[Los Angeles Rams]] [[defensive line]]. * '''G Men''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/teams/story/NYG/5669530 |title=Strahan re-signs with G-Men |accessdate=2007-01-18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060721155140/http://www.nfl.com/teams/story/NYG/5669530 |archivedate=July 21, 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Nickname of the [[New York Giants]]. * '''Gang Green''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philadelphiaeagles.com/news/whereAreTheyNowDetail.jsp?id=18817 |title=Where Are They Now? William Thomas |accessdate=2007-01-18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060317060011/http://www.philadelphiaeagles.com/news/whereAreTheyNowDetail.jsp?id=18817 |archivedate=March 17, 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Nickname of the [[New York Jets]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theganggreen.com|title=New York Jets Fan Site|accessdate=2007-01-18}}</ref> or the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] [[defensive team]] from [[1987 NFL season|1987]] to [[1990 NFL season|1990]], when the team was coached by [[Buddy Ryan]]. *'''[[The Greatest Show on Turf]]''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://football.about.com/b/a/257737.htm|title=Rams Greatest Show or Turf Toe|accessdate=2007-01-18}}</ref> The [[1999 NFL season|1999]]–[[2001 NFL season|2001]] [[St. Louis Rams]] record-breaking [[offensive team]]. They were recognized as one of the greatest offenses to play in NFL history. (Note: The first team referred to as "The Greatest Show on Turf" was the [[1992 NFL season|1992]] [[Houston Oilers]], the title of their 1993 [[NFL Films]] highlight film. The Oilers employed the wide-open [[Run & Shoot|run-and-shoot offense]].)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nd.edu/~observer/10012001/Sports/11.html|title=Pyros cannot escape Lyons den|accessdate=2007-01-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070302193251/http://www.nd.edu/~observer/10012001/Sports/11.html|archive-date=March 2, 2007|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> * '''Gritz Blitz''':<ref name="sportsecyclopedia.com"/> Nickname for the [[1977 Atlanta Falcons season|1977 Atlanta Falcons]] defense that allowed the fewest points per game (9.2) in NFL history. * '''Ground Chuck''':<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-09-02/sports/sp-6258_1_chuck-knox | work=Los Angeles Times | first=Tim | last=Kawakami | date=1992-09-02 | accessdate=2010-05-08 | title=FOOTBALL DAILY REPORT : RAMS : Just Call Him 'Air Chuck'}}</ref> Nickname for the conservative, ball-control offense favored by coach [[Chuck Knox]]. *'''The Iggles''': Nickname for the [[Philadelphia Eagles]]. * '''Homeland Defense''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.patriots.com/games/index.cfm?ac=gamereportdetail&pid=21703&pcid=47|title=Patriots 4-1 at bye; return to action Oct. 22|accessdate=2008-01-30|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519103541/http://www.patriots.com/games/index.cfm?ac=gamereportdetail&pid=21703&pcid=47|archivedate=May 19, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Nickname for the New England Patriots defense during their runs to [[Super Bowl XXXVIII]] and [[Super Bowl XXXIX|XXXIX]]. *'''[[The Hogs (American football)|Hogs]]''': The Washington Redskins' offensive line. During their heydays, they were considered one of the largest and strongest offensive lines in football history, originally consisting of [[Joe Jacoby]], [[Russ Grimm]], [[Mark May]], [[George Starke]], and [[Jeff Bostic]].<ref name="redskins2006">{{cite web|url=http://www.redskins.com/team/cprofile.jsp?id=32 |title=Joe Bugel |accessdate=2007-01-18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061231112638/http://www.redskins.com/team/cprofile.jsp?id=32 |archivedate=2006-12-31 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> * '''Jackson 5''':<ref>http://www.espn.com/blog/jacksonville-jaguars/post/_/id/22959/nickname-for-the-jaguars-secondary-how-about-jackson-5</ref> Nickname of the 2017 [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] secondary coming from [[Jackson 5|the famous music group]] *'''[[Kardiac Kids]]''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsecyclopedia.com/nfl/clev/browns.html|title=Sports E-Cyclopedia History of the Cleveland Browns|accessdate=2007-01-18}}</ref> The [[1980 NFL season|1980]] [[Cleveland Browns]], who had a penchant for having games decided in the final moments. * '''The Killer Bees''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsecyclopedia.com/nfl/miami/dolphins.html|title=Sports E-Cyclopedia History of the Miami Dolphins|accessdate=2007-01-18}}</ref> The [[1982 NFL season|1982]] [[Miami Dolphins]] [[defensive team]]; six of their 11 starters had last names that began with the letter "B" ([[Bob Baumhower]], [[Bill Barnett]], [[Lyle Blackwood]], [[Kim Bokamper]], [[Glenn Blackwood]], [[Charles Bowser]], [[Doug Betters]], and [[Bob Brudzinski]]). They allowed only 131 points in the strike-shortened, nine-game regular season. *'''The Killer B's''': Three members of the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]], consisting of [[Ben Roethlisberger]], [[Le'Veon Bell]], [[Antonio Brown]], and sometimes [[Chris Boswell]]. Name was first used during the [[2016 NFL season]].{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} *'''[[Legion of Boom (Seattle Seahawks)|Legion of Boom]]''': The dominant secondary of the [[Seattle Seahawks]], consisting of All-Pro safety tandem [[Earl Thomas (defensive back)|Earl Thomas]] and [[Kam Chancellor]] as well as the league's largest set of corners in 6'4" Pro Bowler [[Brandon Browner]] and 6'3" All-Pro [[Richard Sherman (American football)|Richard Sherman]]. The term has come to encompass the entire defense.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} *'''[[Marty Ball]]''':<ref>[http://blogs.cjonline.com/index.php?entry=819 CJOnline Blogs – Martyball: The way it's played<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708162302/http://blogs.cjonline.com/index.php?entry=819 |date=2011-07-08 }}</ref> Coach [[Marty Schottenheimer]]'s football strategy. * '''Miami Pound Machine''' The nickname of the late 1980's and early 90's Dolphins defense coming from the band that Gloria Estavan started [[The Miami Sound Machine]]<ref>http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1990-11-30/sports/9002280187_1_miami-pound-machine-dolphin-defense-nickname</ref><ref>http://articles.latimes.com/1990-11-18/sports/sp-6933_1_dolphin-defense</ref> * '''Mile High No Fly Zone''': Self-named defense for the [[2015 Denver Broncos season|2015]] [[Denver Broncos]]. It refers to the team's All-Pro Secondary that included [[Chris Harris Jr.]] and [[Aqib Talib]], combined with a top of the league pass rush led by [[Super Bowl 50]] MVP [[Von Miller]]. [[Wade Phillips]] 3-4 defense led the league in most defensive categories and was wisely considered the best of the NFL. *'''Million Dollar Backfield''' was given to two historical backfields. It was first used to refer to the [[Million Dollar Backfield (Chicago Cardinals)|backfield]] of the then–[[Chicago Cardinals]] in 1947 after owner [[Charles Bidwill]] spent an unprecedented amount of money to lure several of the era's top players to the team.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.profootballhof.com/history/release.aspx?release_id=1701|title=The Cards' dream season in '47|last= |first=|work=History Release|publisher=Pro Football Hall of Fame|accessdate=2010-09-03}}</ref> The term was resurrected again in 1954 for the [[Million Dollar Backfield (San Francisco 49ers)|backfield]] of the [[San Francisco 49ers]], which would go on to produce four [[Pro Football Hall of Fame|Hall of Famers]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/181511-the-san-francisco-49ers-million-dollar-backfield-the-fabulous-foursome |title=San Francisco's Million Dollar Backfield: The 49ers' Fabulous Foursome |last=Tameta |first=Andre |work=Bleacher Report |publisher= |accessdate=2010-09-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609065824/http://bleacherreport.com/articles/181511-the-san-francisco-49ers-million-dollar-backfield-the-fabulous-foursome |archivedate=2011-06-09 |df= }}</ref> *'''[[Monsters of the Midway]]''':<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/bears/2005-11-10-bears-cover_x.htm|title=Monsters of the Midway finally Bearing (sic) their teeth|accessdate=2007-01-18 | work=USA Today | first1=Mike | last1=Dodd | date=2005-11-11}}</ref> Originally applied to the [[Chicago Bears]] of the early 1940s, but revived for the 1980s Bears and subsequent successful Bears defensive teams. Originally used for the [[University of Chicago]] [[Chicago Maroons football|Maroons college football team]]. "Midway" was the name of the park on campus.<ref>''The Wall Street Journal'', 31 October 2009</ref> *'''[[New York Sack Exchange]]''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/teams/story/NYJ/5823858 |title=Sack Exchange Had a Brief, but Glorious, Run |accessdate=2007-01-18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061215001008/http://www.nfl.com/teams/story/NYJ/5823858 |archivedate=December 15, 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The [[New York Jets]] defense of the early 1980s, led by defensive end [[Mark Gastineau]] along with [[Joe Klecko]], and interior linemen [[Marty Lyons]] and [[Abdul Salaam (football player)|Abdul Salaam]]. Fans began showing up at Shea Stadium with "NY Sack Exchange" signs, then the team itself began to promote that moniker.<ref>New York Newsday, December 8, 2002, page 38, Jets Confidential Magazine, Vol 10, Num. 16, page 23 [https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/newsday/access/256929861.html?dids=256929861:256929861&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Dec+8%2C+2002&author=Bob+Herzog.+STAFF+WRITER&pub=Newsday&edition=&startpage=B.8&desc=Time+to+Take+Stock+Of++Sack+Exchange+%2F++Defensive+unit+considers+its+place+in+history Time to Take Stock Of Sack Exchange / Defensive unit considers its place in history]</ref> Name references the [[New York Stock Exchange]] on New York's [[Wall Street]]. * '''No-Name Defense''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/6844229 |title=Flashback: Playing to perfection |accessdate=2007-01-18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051115150217/http://www.nfl.com/news/story/6844229 |archivedate=November 15, 2005 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The 1970s [[Miami Dolphins]] defensive team, especially that of its [["The Perfect Season"|undefeated 1972 season]], which performed excellently despite a lack of recognizable stars. They earned their nickname the previous year when Dallas coach [[Tom Landry]] said in an interview prior to [[Super Bowl VI]] that he could not remember the names of the Miami defensive players. *'''[[Orange Crush Defense|Orange Crush]]''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/teams/story/DEN/4993136 |title=Gehrke helped build "Orange Crush" |accessdate=2007-01-18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061210101113/http://www.nfl.com/teams/story/DEN/4993136 |archivedate=December 10, 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The 1970s [[Denver Broncos]] [[defensive team]], led by defensive end [[Lyle Alzado]] and linebacker [[Randy Gradishar]]. *'''[[The Over-the-Hill Gang (American football)|Over-the-Hill Gang]]''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/teams/story/DAL/5933826 |title='72 Redskins haven't lost their spirit |accessdate=2007-01-18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061214200040/http://www.nfl.com/teams/story/DAL/5933826 |archivedate=December 14, 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The [[George Allen (American football coach)|George Allen]]–coached [[Washington Redskins]] of the early 1970s, so named because of the large number of veteran players on the team. Many of those players also played for Allen when he coached the [[Los Angeles Rams]] from [[1966 NFL season|1966]]–[[1970 NFL season|1970]]. * '''Patsies''':<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,946720-1,00.html|title=New England: Patsies No More|accessdate=2007-01-18 | work=Time | date=1976-10-18}}</ref> Poorly performing [[New England Patriots]] squads, a play on the nickname "The Pats". * '''Purple Pain''': This [[Baltimore Ravens]] nickname stems from the team's color, purple. It is also an allusion to the [[Purple Rain (film)|movie]] and [[Purple Rain (song)|song "Purple Rain"]]. *'''[[Purple People Eaters]]''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.grandstandsports.com/sport5.aspx?itemid=10989|title=Purple People Eaters|accessdate=2007-01-18}}</ref> The 1970s [[Minnesota Vikings]] [[defensive line]], specifically the combination of [[Alan Page]], [[Jim Marshall (gridiron football)|Jim Marshall]], [[Carl Eller]], and [[Gary Larsen]]. The name is a reference to both the purple uniforms of the Vikings and the 1958 [[Sheb Wooley]] song "Purple People Eater." * '''Purple Murder''': The [[Baltimore Ravens]]' color is purple. A group of crows is called a "murder of crows", and Ravens are similar to crows. Technically, a group of Ravens is referred to as an "unkindness of ravens". Purple Unkindness is a less catchy nickname. In addition, [[Ray Lewis]], a longtime member of the Ravens, was [[Ray Lewis#Murder trial|implicated in a murder case]] during his playing career, possibly popularizing the phrase.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://longstreet.typepad.com/thesciencebookstore/2009/07/an-unkindness-of-ravens-a-murder-of-crows-naming-things.html|title=An Unkindness of Ravens; a Murder of Crows. Naming Things.|website=JF Ptak Science Books|accessdate=December 29, 2017}}</ref> * '''Sack Pack''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.footballoutsiders.com/walkthrough/2007/every-stat-tells-story-1981-colts|title=Sack Pack|accessdate=2010-09-23}}</ref> The defensive line of the Baltimore Colts in the mid-to-late 1970s. The Sack Pack were defensive tackles Joe Ehrmann (#76) and Mike Barnes (#63) and defensive ends Fred Cook (#72) and John Dutton (#78). In 1975, the Sack Pack established itself with 59 sacks. It had 56 the following year and 47 in 1977 before slowing down due to injuries. *'''[[Sacksonville]]''': A [[portmanteau]] of the word [[Quarterback sack|sack]] and the city of [[Jacksonville]]. "Sacksonville" is used to refer to the [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] defense which is known to cause a high number of sacks, interceptions, and turnovers *'''[[San Diego Super Chargers]]''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/9847410 |title=Upon further review: Week 13 |accessdate=2007-01-18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070114044405/http://www.nfl.com/news/story/9847410 |archivedate=January 14, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Nickname given to the [[San Diego Chargers]] from its [[fight song]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chargers.com/fan_zone/super-charger-song.htm |title=San Diego Super Chargers Song |accessdate=2007-11-01 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011110249/http://chargers.com/fan_zone/super-charger-song.htm |archivedate=October 11, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CepkO_buVEk|title=San Diego Super Chargers|accessdate=2007-11-01}}</ref> The song is often cited by [[Chris Berman]] and [[Tom Jackson (American football, born 1951)|Tom Jackson]]. *'''[[Steel Curtain]]''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsecyclopedia.com/nfl/pitt/steelers.html|title=Sports E-Cyclopedia History of the Pittsburgh Steelers|accessdate=2007-01-18}}</ref> Nickname given to the defensive line of the 1970s [[Pittsburgh Steelers]], the backbone of a dominant defense. The nickname was a play on the phrase [[Iron Curtain]] during the height of the [[Cold War]]. * '''Sons of Anarchy''': The New York Jets defensive line of the early 2010s consisting of Muhammad Wilker'''son''', Damon Harri'''son''', and Sheldon Richard'''son'''. Alludes to the [[Sons of Anarchy|FX television series of the same name]] which was highly popular at the time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/new-york/jets/post/_/id/31061/fans-name-d-line-the-sons-of-anarchy|title=Fans name D-line the 'Sons of Anarchy'|website=go.com|accessdate=December 29, 2017}}</ref> * '''SWAT team''':<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/01/17/sports/super-bowl-xxiii-bengals-hope-defense-will-stay-offensive.html|title=SUPER BOWL XXIII; Bengals Hope Defense Will Stay Offensive|date=1989-01-17 | work=The New York Times | first=Gerald | last=Eskenazi | accessdate=2010-05-08}}</ref> Name of the Cincinnati Bengals' secondary of [[David Fulcher]], [[Solomon Wilcots]], [[Eric Thomas (American football)|Eric Thomas]], and [[Lewis Billups]] coached by Defensive Coordinator [[Dick LeBeau]] during the 1988 season. * '''Three Amigos''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denverbroncos.com/page.php?id=334&storyID=2428|title=Denver Broncos: Elway – Through the Years: 1987|accessdate=2007-01-12}}</ref> [[Denver Broncos]] wide receivers [[Mark Jackson (American football player)|Mark Jackson]], [[Vance Johnson]], and [[Ricky Nattiel]] * '''The Triplets''':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsecyclopedia.com/nfl/dallas/cowboys.html|title=Sports E-cyclopedia: Dallas Cowboys, see 2005 |accessdate=2007-03-15}}</ref> [[Troy Aikman]], [[Michael Irvin]] and [[Emmitt Smith]], the offensive stars of the 1990s [[Dallas Cowboys]] three-time Super Bowl winning teams
==Players== Nicknames for individual players, or small groups of individual players.
