{{Use British English|date=August 2015}} {{About|the museum in the United Kingdom|the museum in Germany|German Football Museum}} {{Infobox museum | image = Urbis Olympics.jpg | imagesize = 230 | caption = The National Football Museum | alt = | map_type = | map_caption = | map_alt = | coordinates = | established = February 2001 | dissolved = | location = [[Urbis]], [[Manchester]] (2012–)
[[Deepdale]], [[Preston, Lancashire|Preston]] (2001–2010) | type = Sports museum | collection = | visitors = 574,000 (2016){{cite web|url=http://www.alva.org.uk/details.cfm?p=607 |title=Visits made in 2016 to visitor attractions in membership with ALVA |work=ALVA |accessdate=23 March 2018}}
| director = | president = [[Bobby Charlton|Sir Bobby Charlton]] | curator = | publictransit =[[Manchester Victoria railway station|Manchester Victoria]] [[File:National Rail logo.svg|10px]] [[File:Manchester metrolink logo.PNG|10px]]
[[Exchange Square tram stop|Exchange Square]][[File:Manchester metrolink logo.PNG|10px]]
[[Metroshuttle]] {{rail-interchange|bus}} (Routes 1 & 2) | network = | website = [http://www.nationalfootballmuseum.com nationalfootballmuseum.com] }} The '''National Football Museum''' is England’s national museum of [[Football in England|football]]. It is based in the [[Urbis]] building in [[Manchester]] city centre, and preserves, conserves and displays important collections of [[association football|football]] memorabilia. As a publicly funded national museum, entrance is free. The museum was originally based in [[Deepdale]], [[Preston, Lancashire|Preston]], [[Lancashire]], but moved to Manchester in 2012.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-manchester-18725667|title=Why football museum moved to Manchester|last=Airey|first=Tom|date=2012-07-06|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-11-28|language=en-GB}} ==History== [[File:Finney.jpg|thumb|left|Statue recreating the famous [[Tom Finney]] "Splash" photo outside the old National Football Museum.]] The idea for what became the National Football Museum goes back to 1994 when Baxi Partnership, a local company, acquired Preston North End Football Club (PNE) and began the redevelopment of Deepdale Stadium. A chance conversation between Bryan Gray, Chairman of PNE, and the Football League, led to a meeting with Harry Langton, the man who over thirty years put together what is now called the FIFA Museum Collection. FIFA recognised the importance of the collection and acquired it from Harry Langton with a view to finding a permanent home. FIFA saw the proposed museum at Preston as an ideal permanent location for the FIFA Museum Collection.{{Citation needed|date=November 2017}} Bryan Gray formed a small team of people to work on the project including Keith Cooper of FIFA, David Fleming, Director of Tyne and Wear Museums, Brian Booth, formerly Vice Chancellor of the University of Central Lancashire, and Chris Newbery, director of the Royal Marines Museum in Portsmouth. The Football Association was represented by David Davies. The National Football Museum was incorporated as a private limited company in June 1995 and became a registered charity in November 1995.{{Citation needed|date=November 2017}} After much hard work, an application to the Heritage Lottery Fund was successful and a grant of £7.5m was awarded in November 1997. The total project cost was estimated at £12m. A ground breaking ceremony took place on 26 September 1998 by Sepp Blatter of FIFA with the Rt Hon Chris Smith in attendance. The foundation stone was laid by Bryan Gray and Ben Casey (who had persuaded Baxi to buy PNE) in April 2000. Finally the National Football Museum was officially opened on 21 June 2001 by HRH The Duke of Kent. Bryan Gray, the founding chairman of trustees, stood down in September 2001 to be succeeded by Brian Booth. Rob Pratten was the first employee of the Football Museum: he joined the team in May 1995 and for some time was the only employee. Kevin Moore was appointed Director in August 1997 and was later joined by Mark Bushell, Hugh Hornby and Lindsey Jones. The museum's first site was outside [[Deepdale]], [[Preston, Lancashire|Preston]], [[Lancashire]]. Deepdale was particularly significant as it is the oldest continuously used football league ground in the world. The museum's president is [[1966 World Cup final|World Cup winner]] [[Bobby Charlton|Sir Bobby Charlton]]. In 2003 the museum and the [[University of Central Lancashire]] established the [[International Football Institute]] to conduct research into historical, social and cultural aspects of football.{{citation |title=International Football Institute |publisher=University of Central Lancashire |url=http://www.uclan.ac.uk/schools/ssto/research/international_football_institute.php |accessdate=8 July 2012}} On a visit in 2004, [[Sepp Blatter]], President of [[FIFA]] commented "''The National Football Museum merits my admiration as a footballer and as the President of FIFA — it is a superb realisation, a real jewel!''". Sir Bobby Charlton commented that he ''“can’t think of a better museum anywhere in the world.”'' and [[Alex Ferguson|Sir Alex Ferguson]] "''Each time I visit the Museum I am so impressed by the great job it does in bringing the rich history of football to life''".{{citation |title=A step back in time |url=https://www.fifa.com/aboutfifa/organisation/news/newsid=752588/index.html |date=25 April 2008 |accessdate=8 July 2012 |publisher=FIFA}} The museum received the award of Large Visitor Attraction of the Year, at the 2005 Lancashire and Blackpool Tourism Awards{{citation |title=Football museum's expansion plan |publisher=BBC News |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/lancashire/5149092.stm |date=5 July 2006 |accessdate=7 July 2012}} In December 2008, chairman of the [[Football League]], [[Brian Mawhinney]] caused controversy when he suggested that the Museum should be moved from Preston to [[Wembley Stadium]] in order to attract more visitors. Founder Kevin Moore, stated that it had been an aim to have an exhibition at Wembley, but stated that the trustee's policy was to have its headquarters in Preston.{{citation |url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/history+%26+heritage/art63465 |title=National Football Museum Vows To Pick Preston Over Wembley |publisher=Culture 24 |date=16 December 2008 |accessdate=7 July 2012}}{{citation |title=Minister backs city's claim to football museum |newspaper=Lancashire Evening Post |date=26 December 2008 |url=http://www.lep.co.uk/news/local/minister-backs-city-s-claim-to-football-museum-1-85013 |accessdate=8 July 2012}} Despite critical acclaim and attracting 100,000 visitors per year,{{citation |title=Hands off, Wembley |newspaper=New Statesman |url=http://www.newstatesman.com/sport/2009/03/football-museum-preston |first=Hunter |last=Davies |date=12 March 2009 |accessdate=7 July 2012}}{{citation |title=MPs fight moving football museum |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/lancashire/7780288.stm |date=12 December 2008 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=7 July 2012}}{{citation |newspaper=Lancashire Evening Post |title=Manchester United legend: Museum should stay in Preston |url=http://www.lep.co.uk/news/local/manchester-united-legend-museum-should-stay-in-preston-1-98129 |date=9 September 2009 |accessdate=7 July 2012}} funding was repeatedly an issue.{{citation |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/lancashire/4094452.stm |title=Football Museum jobs under threat |publisher=BBC News |date=15 June 2005 |accessdate=8 July 2012}}{{citation |title=Football museum 'needs more cash' |publisher= BBC News |accessdate=8 July 2012 |date=23 January 2007 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/lancashire/6289689.stm}} In 2007, it had an income of £791,256 against out-goings of £1,231,195.{{citation |url=http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/news/s/1135614_national_football_museum_moves_to_manchester |first=David |last=Ottewell |title=National Football Museum moves to Manchester |newspaper=Manchester Evening News |date=8 September 2009 |accessdate=8 July 2012}} The trustees were concerned about the museum's long-term future. In 2009, they approached Manchester City Council about moving the museum. The city council offered a funding package worth £2m per year for the museum to move to Manchester. Despite an improved offer of £400,000 per year from [[City of Preston, Lancashire|Preston]] and [[Lancashire]] councils, the trustees voted to move the museum to the [[Urbis]] exhibition centre in [[Manchester]].{{citation |title=National Football Museum to move to Urbis |url=http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/news/s/1182980_national_football_museum_to_move_to_urbis |date=18 November 2009 |newspaper=Manchester Evening News |accessdate=23 October 2010}} It was intended that subject to satisfactory funding, the Preston site would remain open as a secondary centre. However, the museum failed to agree a funding package with Lancashire County Council and the Preston site closed to the public at the end of April 2010.{{citation |title=National Football Museum closes its doors in Preston |publisher=BBC News |date=1 May 2010 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/lancashire/8655373.stm |accessdate=7 July 2012}}{{citation |title=National Football Museum in Preston to close |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/lancashire/8630976.stm |date=19 April 2010 |accessdate=7 July 2012 |publisher=BBC News}} As of 2012, the Preston site is still used as a research and storage centre. Urbis closed in February 2010 in preparation for an intended opening of the new National Football Museum in summer 2011.{{Cite news |title=Manchester's Urbis closes to become football museum |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/8540418.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 February 2010 |accessdate=23 October 2010}} The museum reopened in Manchester on 6 July 2012. It is hoped that the new museum will attract 350,000 visitors per year.{{citation |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-manchester-18725667 |publisher=BBC News |date=6 July 2012 |title=National Football Museum opens at new Manchester home |first=Tom |last=Airey |accessdate=7 July 2012}} It was reported in August 2012 that the new National Football Museum attracted over 100,000 visitors in the first six weeks of opening.{{Cite news |title=Museum welcomes 100,000th visitor |url=http://www.nationalfootballmuseum.com/about-us/latest-news/2012/08/museum-welcomes-100000th-visitor/ |work=National Football Museum |date=21 August 2012 |accessdate=27 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121010091630/http://www.nationalfootballmuseum.com/about-us/latest-news/2012/08/museum-welcomes-100000th-visitor/ |archivedate=10 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }} By the end of April 2013, the museum reached its 350,000 target.{{Cite news |title=Back of the net: National Football Museum smashes targets for visitors |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/national-football-museum-urbis-manchester-3158075 |work=Manchester Evening News |date=26 April 2013 |accessdate=7 May 2013}} ==Building layout== [[File:National Football Museum (7560277168).jpg|thumb|right|Inside the museum, looking down from the top floor]] The museum is based in the [[Urbis]] building and is laid out over 4 floors:
'''Level One''' – The largest floor, housing the zones: * The Game – Features items such as the first ever rule book from 1863 and the shirt from the first ever international football match between England and Scotland * Fans – Including the original painting of L.S. Lowry's "Going to the Match" * Competition – Information about the various competitions and leagues, with the original version of the FA Cup and various replica trophies * The Global Game – A section dedicated to world football, with the ball from the first ever World Cup Final, the [[match ball]] from the 1966 World Cup Final, Maradona's "Hand of God" shirt and the UEFA Cup Winners Cup trophy. * Stadiums – Information about various stadiums and designs, with an original turnstile from the old Wembley Stadium and some original wooden seats. * Media – Featuring various footage and clippings from old matches, including a sheepskin coat worn by John Motson. * Clubs – Interactive screens with information on most league clubs in England. * Players – A brief look at the scope of footballers, including the only Victoria Cross won by a professional footballer and the painting "The Art of the Game" portraying Eric Cantona. * Our Beautiful Game – A 10-minute film in a cinema showcasing a month in English football on all levels.
'''Level Two''' – Featuring various paid-for football interactive games, as well the zones: * Football for All – A showcase of how football is played by people of all abilities. * Laws – Interactive screens explaining the original rules of football and referees roles in the game. * Managers – Audio clips from managers and the original Manager of the Year trophy. * Toys and Games – A showcase of various football-related games and toys * Performance – Information about the medical side of playing football, including Willie Cunninghams knee cartilage and Tommy Lawtons ashes. * Discovery Zone – An area for under-5's to play.
'''Level Three''' – A changing exhibition space. In summer 2016, it hosted an exhibition celebrating 50th anniversary of [[England national football team|England]]'s [[1966 FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] triumph.
'''Level Four''' – Learning and Education zone, currently featuring a small exhibition called "Our Sporting Life"
'''Level Five and Six''' – The Suite- Event Space (Previously a restaurant called 'Kaleido', which closed in 2013{{cite news|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/restaurants-bars/fine-dining-restaurant-kaleido-close-5389124|title=Fine dining restaurant Kaleido to close after just a YEAR after it was launched at the top of National Football Museum|author=Dianne Bourne|date=31 July 2013|work=Manchester Evening News}}) ==Collections== Located at the [[Deepdale]] stadium in [[Preston, Lancashire|Preston]], where the museum was open from June 2001 – March 2010, the independent [[Charitable organization|charity]] holds the following collections at its research facility: * The [[FIFA]] Museum Collection * [[The Football Association]] Collection * [[The Football League]] Collection. * The [[FIFA]] Book Collection * The People’s Collection * The Football Clubs Collection * The [[Harry Langton Collection]] * The [[Stanley Matthews|Sir Stanley Matthews]] Collection * The [[Littlewoods]] Collection * The Priory Collection * The Neville Evans Collection The Neville Evans collection forms part of the largest private collection of football memorabilia in the world. Also known as the National Football Collection, it consists of a wide range of football-related items, including the largest private collection of [[Tottenham Hotspur]] memorabilia in the world. At least 400 items are on long-term loan to the National Football Museum, with other items also being supplied to complement their in house and travelling exhibits. Started by UK businessman Neville Evans, the collection continues to grow and works to preserve and share the history of football for the next generation of fans. * The Homes of Football – photography by Stuart Roy Clarke At any time, around 2,500 items from the museum’s collections are on display at its new home in Manchester city centre, with around a further 140,000 items held. Key items include{{citation |title=It's kicking off in Manchester – the new National Football Museum opens today |newspaper=The Guardian |date=6 July 2012 |accessdate=8 July 2012 |first=Gavin |last=McOwan |url=https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2012/jul/06/new-national-football-museum-manchester?newsfeed=true}} * Both of the two balls used in the first [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] Final in 1930. * The ball from the [[1966 FIFA World Cup Final|1966 World Cup Final]]. * The replica of the [[Jules Rimet Trophy]], made in secret by the FA in 1966 after the original was [[Theft of the Jules Rimet Trophy|stolen]], and paraded by the England players at the World Cup Final in 1966. * The [[Cuthbert Ottaway|England captain’s]] jersey and cap from the world’s first official international football match, Scotland vs England,{{cite news | title = The first international football match | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/scotland/sportscotland/asportingnation/article/0012/index.shtml | publisher = [[bbc.co.uk]] | author = [[Paul Mitchell (broadcaster)|Paul Mitchell]] | date = | accessdate =19 April 2012}} in 1872. * The world’s oldest women’s football kit, from the 1890s. * The shirt worn by [[Maradona]] during the '[[Hand of God goal]]' and [[Hand of God goal#The Goal of the Century|The Goal of the Century]]. * The [[Laws of the Game (association football)|original rules]] of [[Association Football]] written down when [[The Football Association]] was formed in 1863 in the Freemasons Tavern, London. == Gallery == File:Original laws of the game 1863.jpg|The original 'Laws of the game' drafted for and behalf of [[The Football Association]] in 1863. File:1896 FA Cup.jpg|The oldest surviving [[FA_Cup#Trophy|FA Cup trophy]] (1896-1910). File:Meredith shirt.jpg|Wales shirt which worn by [[Billy Meredith]] against England and Ireland in 1908. File:1930 World Cup Final ball Argentina.jpg|Football used in the [[1930 FIFA World Cup Final|1930 World Cup Final]], chosen by the [[Argentina national football team|Argentine team]] and used in the first half. File:National Football Museum Manchester 5732 (14200154631).jpg|Club Pennants of the Football League's founder members. File:Silverware (8060374775).jpg|Trophies and awards. ==Exhibitions== Many exhibits are loaned to museums in the UK and artifacts have been loaned to exhibitions in Germany, Portugal, Switzerland and Belgium. The museum has worked in partnership with UEFA to create the UEFA Jubilee Exhibition, which opened in the European Parliament in Brussels, before moving to the National Football Museum. The museum also worked with UEFA to create the world’s first exhibition dedicated to women’s football, to coincide with the UEFA Euro 2005 Women’s Championship. To mark the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] the museum worked with partners to develop exhibitions in [[Hong Kong]] and [[Germany]]. A special exhibition "Saved for the Nation: The Story of the FA Cup" which featured the oldest surviving [[FA Cup trophy]], used during FA Cup Finals between 1896 and 1910, was launched in May 2006. The museum's temporary exhibitions programme has also included "One for All: All for One", a photographic exhibition highlighting the work of Philip Colvin, documenting the experiences and challenges of disabled [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] supporter Samuel Burch as he travelled across the country in support of his team); and "The Greater Game: Football and The First World War", exploring the role football played at home and at the front during the war years, and explores the myths and reality of famous stories from the conflict, including a previously unseen diary detailing the events of the famous [[Christmas Truce]] of 1914, as well as lost footage from the front and of wartime football. *Saved for the Nation: The Story of the [[FA Cup]] - May 2006 *One for All: All for One - March 2007 to June 2007 *The Greater Game: Football and The [[First World War]] - December 2014 *Out of Play: [[Goal-line technology|Technology]] in Football - May 2015 *[[Ferenc Puskás]]: The World's Greatest Goalscorer - September 2015 *Pitch to Pixel: The World of Football Gaming - October 2015 to June 2016 *[[1966 World Cup]] Exhibition - June 2016 to April 2017 ==Publications== *{{citation |title=Eyewitness Football, |publisher=Dorling Kindersley |isbn=9781405366021 |year=2010 |first=Hugh |last=Hornby}} *{{citation |title=Football's Greatest Heroes: The National Football Museum Hall of Fame |isbn=9781861059048 |publisher=Robson |first1=Robert |last1=Galvin |first2=Mark |last2=Bushell |first3=Bobby |last3=Charlton |date=1 October 2005}} *{{ citation |title=Treasures of the World Cup,|isbn=1844423212 |publisher=Carlton Books Limited |first1=Keir |last1=Radnedge |first2=Mark |last2=Bushell |first3=Gary |last3=Lineker |date=1 April 2006}} ==See also== * [[English Football Hall of Fame]], which is housed at the museum ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * {{official|http://www.nationalfootballmuseum.com/}} * [http://www.uclan.ac.uk/ifi International Football Institute]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [http://www.priorycollection.com/ Priory Collection] * [http://www.thenationalfootballcollection.org.uk/ National Football Collection (Neville Evans)] {{Football in England}} {{Museums and galleries in Greater Manchester}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Coord|53|29|08|N|2|14|31|W|type:landmark_region:GB-MAN|display=title}} [[Category:History of Preston]] [[Category:Museums in Manchester]] [[Category:Sports museums in England]] [[Category:History of football in England]] [[Category:Association football museums and halls of fame]] [[Category:2001 establishments in England]] [[Category:Museums established in 2001]]

{{Refimprove|date=May 2009}} {{Infobox convention center | name = Neal S. Blaisdell Center | image = | image_caption = | address = 777 Ward Ave
[[Honolulu]], [[Hawaii]] 96814-2166 | location = [[Downtown Honolulu]], [[Oahu]] | coordinates = | owner = [[Honolulu County, Hawaii|City and County of Honolulu]] | operator = | built = | opened = {{Start date|1964|09|12}}{{cite web |url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2007/Jul/30/op/hawaii707300304.html |title=Elvis statue at Blaisdell just the beginning |last1=Budnick |first1=Rich |last2= |first2= |date=July 30, 2007 |website=[[The Honolulu Advertiser]] |publisher=[[Black Press]] |accessdate=January 10, 2014}}{{cite web|last=Gordon|first=Mike|title=Golden memories: For a half-century, Blaisdell Center has played a big role in our lives through concerts, graduations and sports|website=[[Honolulu Star-Advertiser]]|date=January 12, 2014|url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/s?action=login&f=y&id=239740591|accessdate=January 15, 2014}} | inaugurated = | renovated = 1994 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | construction_cost= [[United States dollar|$]]14 million | former_names = Honolulu International Center (1964-76) | classroom_cap = 72 (Oahu Room)
64 (Maui Room)
48 (Kauai Room) | banquets = 1,000 (Hawaii Suite)
700 (Pikake Room)
350 (Carla Coray Galleria) | theatre = 8,800 (Blaisdell Arena)
2,157 (Blaisdell Concert Hall) | total_space = | exhibit = {{convert|65000|sqft|m2}} | breakout = {{convert|3200|sqft|m2}} | ballroom = {{convert|23700|sqft|m2}} | website = {{URL|http://blaisdellcenter.com/|Venue Website}} }} The '''Neal S. Blaisdell Center''' near [[downtown Honolulu]], [[Hawaii]] is a community center for the [[Honolulu County, Hawaii|City & County of Honolulu]]."[http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/MapItDrawServlet?geo_id=16000US1517000&_bucket_id=50&tree_id=420&context=saff&_lang=en&_sse=on Honolulu CDP, HI]." ''[[U.S. Census Bureau]]''. Retrieved on May 21, 2009. Constructed in 1964 on the historic Ward Estate and originally called the '''Honolulu International Center''', the center was renamed after [[Mayor of Honolulu]] [[Neal S. Blaisdell]], who oversaw its construction. The multi-purpose complex is composed of an internationally renowned arena, concert hall, conference rooms, galleria and exhibition hall. It was remodeled and expanded in 1994. The complex is overseen by the City's Department of Enterprise Services which also oversees the [[Waikiki Shell]]. The City is seeking to redevelop the site with extensive stakeholder and public involvement to assess the community’s goals. Implementation of this plan will require significant investment by the City and its partners over the coming years, and the outcome will be an iconic symbol of the City and County of Honolulu.{{Cite web|url=https://www.honolulu.gov/tod/dpp-tod-implementation/dpp-tod-projects/dpp-tod-blaisdell.html|title=Blaisdell Center|website=www.honolulu.gov|access-date=2016-10-03}} ==Facilities and events== ===Arena=== [[File:Blaisdell Arena - Honolulu 10-Feb-2010.jpg|thumb|Blaisdell Arena|200px|left]] The '''Neal S. Blaisdell Arena''' is a circular performance facility used for concerts and major sporting events. The arena can accommodate 7,700 seats for sports events, and up to 8,800 seats for stage events with seats set up on the arena floor. [[Elvis Presley]]'s "[[Aloha from Hawaii]]" concert was held here on January 14, 1973. In recognition of the concert, a bronze statue of Elvis was installed in 2007 outside the front of the arena. The statue was sponsored by the cable channel [[TV Land]].http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2007/Jul/26/br/br7634109285.html Other events at the arena include [[WWE]], [[Disney on Ice]], [[American Idol]] Live!, [[Sesame Street Live]], college [[basketball]] and [[volleyball]], and international [[gymnastics]], as well as a fundraising concert for victims of Hurricane Iniki, with [[Crosby, Stills & Nash]], [[Jackson Browne]] & [[Bonnie Raitt]], and a 1965 [[Billy Graham]] crusade. Other music artists that have performed at the arena include [[Mariah Carey]], [[Metallica]], [[Aerosmith]], [[Van Halen]], [[Bon Jovi]], [[Elton John]], [[Journey (band)|Journey]], [[Santana (band)|Santana]] and [[Bruno Mars]]. During a circus performance in 1994, Tyke, an African Elephant, killed her trainer and charged out of the arena in rage. The animal rampaged outside the arena for 30 minutes before police fired 86 rounds at the elephant, who eventually collapsed and died as a result of the shootings. The Philippine TV show [[ASAP (TV series)|ASAP]] performed at the Neal S. Blaisdell Arena on June 30, 2018 through an international concert titled ASAP Live in Honolulu. ===Sports=== The Arena also hosts the start of the exhibition season for the [[Los Angeles Lakers]] of the [[National Basketball Association]] and the men's and women's basketball and volleyball games for [[Hawaii Pacific University]], the state's largest private university. It served as the home court for [[University of Hawaii at Manoa|University of Hawai{{okina}}i at Mānoa]] basketball until UH built the [[Stan Sheriff Center]] on campus in 1994. The arena was the home venue for several short-lived attempts to establish Hawaii professional sports teams, including the [[Billings Volcanos|Hawaii Volcanos]] of the [[Continental Basketball Association]], the Hawaii Hurricanes of the [[American Basketball Association (2000-)|American Basketball Association]], the [[Hawaii Leis]] of [[World Team Tennis]] and three indoor football teams: the [[Honolulu Hurricanes]], the [[Hawaii Hammerheads]], and the [[af2]]'s [[Hawaiian Islanders]]. The Leis and Islanders each persisted for three full seasons, the longest of all the pro teams based at the arena. In 1982, the arena served as home court for [[Chaminade Silverswords|Chaminade University]] in a Christmas Eve [[1982 Virginia vs. Chaminade men's basketball game|upset]] of a [[Ralph Sampson]]-led number one ranked [[1982–83 Virginia Cavaliers men's basketball team|University of Virginia]], 77-72. In November 2006, the [[Professional Bull Riders]] hosted the Cheeseburger Island Style PBR Hawaii All-Star Challenge, a special event that took place between the 2006 PBR World Finals and the start of the 2007 PBR season. Many graduation and commencement ceremonies are held by schools in the arena and concert hall in late May and June. The arena also hosts the [[WWE]]'s flagship shows, ''[[WWE Raw|Raw]]'' and ''[[WWE SmackDown|SmackDown LIVE]]'' for two nights, starts from June 25 to 26, 2018. ===Concert Hall=== [[File:Blaisdell Concert Hall - Honolulu 10-Feb-2010.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Blaisdell Concert Hall]] With a capacity of 2,158 seats, the '''Neal S. Blaisdell Concert Hall''' is the home of the [[Honolulu Symphony]] and the [[Hawaii Opera Theatre|Hawai{{okina}}i Opera Theatre]]. [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] productions such as ''[[The Phantom of the Opera (1986 musical)|The Phantom of the Opera]]'', ''[[Les Misérables (musical)|Les Misérables]]'', ''[[Rent (musical)|Rent]]'', ''[[Miss Saigon]]'', ''[[Chicago (musical)|Chicago]]'', ''[[Cats (musical)|Cats]]'', and other national touring shows have performed at the concert hall.[http://www.blaisdellcenter.com/venues/concerthall.html "Neal S. Blaisdell - Venues - Concert Hall" at BlaisdellCenter.com]. Retrieved 10 February 2010. In the fall and early winter of 2007 the concert hall was host to the Broadway musical ''[[The Lion King (musical)|The Lion King]]'', a booking which displaced the Honolulu Symphony from its usual home and led to a major cash flow crisis for the orchestra.Westphal, Matthew. [http://www.playbillarts.com/news/article/7518.html "Honolulu Symphony Runs Out of Money to Pay Musicians", ''Playbill Arts'', 20 December 2007]. Retrieved 10 February 2010. ===Exhibition Hall=== [[File:Blaisdell Exhibition Hall.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Inside the Blaisdell Exhibition Hall]] Located between the Concert Hall and the Arena, the Exhibition Hall provides {{convert|65000|sqft|m2}} of exhibition space on the main floor that is expandable to {{convert|85000|sqft|m2}} when combined with adjoining spaces. Five meeting rooms are also available in the hall. The Exhibition Hall accommodates numerous local trade and consumer shows and fundraising events throughout the year, and is one of the main exhibition venues in Honolulu in addition to the [[Hawaii Convention Center]]. The Exhibition Hall hosts events throughout the year such as craft fairs, gun shows, family expos, job fairs, food & product shows, as well as private tradeshows. ===Miscellaneous=== Many religious ceremonies have been performed in the Neal S. Blaisdell Center. The largest of which were the enthronement of [[Joseph Anthony Ferrario]] as the third [[Roman Catholic Bishop of Honolulu|Bishop of Honolulu]] and the ordination and installation of [[Clarence Richard Silva]] as the fifth Bishop of Honolulu, overseeing the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Honolulu]]. [[Kamehameha Schools]] has held their annual [[Kamehameha Schools Song Contest|Song Contest]] at the Blaisdell since 1964. On December 23, 1982, what is considered by many as the greatest upset in sports history happened at the Blaisdell Arena as the then number 1-ranked [[University of Virginia]] [[1982–83 Virginia Cavaliers men's basketball team|Cavaliers]], led by future [[List of players in the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame|Hall of Famer]] [[Ralph Sampson]], were beaten 77-72 by [[Chaminade Silverswords|Chaminade University]], a small [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics|NAIA]] school (today [[NCAA Division II]]) with a student body of 800. ==See also== *[[List of concert halls]] *[[Tyke (elephant)|Tyke the elephant]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{coord|21.29991|N|157.85062|W|region:US-HI_type:landmark|display=title}} {{Hawaii Rainbow Warriors basketball navbox}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Blaisdell Center, Neal S.}} [[Category:Hawaii Rainbow Warriors and Rainbow Wahine basketball]] [[Category:Hawaiian architecture]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Hawaii]] [[Category:Convention centers in Hawaii]] [[Category:Concert halls in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in Hawaii]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Honolulu]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Honolulu]] [[Category:Music venues in Hawaii]] [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1964]] [[Category:1964 establishments in Hawaii]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1964]] [[Category:Continental Basketball Association venues]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Hawaii]]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = North Greenwich | nickname = | image = | caption = | location = [[North Greenwich, Isle of Dogs|North Greenwich]]
[[Isle of Dogs]]
[[London]], [[England]] | coordinates = | built = 1901 | opened = 21 September 1901 | closed = 8 October 1910 | construction_cost = | surface = Grass | scoreboard = | former names = | tenants = [[Millwall Athletic F.C.]] (1901–1910) | seating_capacity = 16,300 (standing) | dimensions = }} '''North Greenwich''' was a [[association football|football]] ground and the home of [[Millwall Athletic F.C.|Millwall Athletic Football Club]] from 1901–1910, the team who went on to become [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]].{{sfn|Tarrant|Lindsay|2010|page=19}} It was situated on the [[Isle of Dogs]], [[East London]]. It was the fourth stadium that Millwall have occupied since their formation as a football club in 1885, and their last East London ground before they moved to [[South London]].{{cite web |title = Millwall History |url = http://www.millwallfc.co.uk/club/history/ |publisher = Millwall F.C. |accessdate = 5 September 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121001154410/http://www.millwallfc.co.uk/club/history/ |archivedate = 1 October 2012}}{{cite web| title = Millwall origins| url = http://www.millwall-history.co.uk/origins.htm|work=The Millwall History Files| accessdate =28 August 2010}} ==History== Millwall Athletic were forced to leave their third ground, [[The Athletic Grounds]] after the Millwall Dock Company told them they wanted to use it as a timberyard. The last game at the Athletic Grounds was a 4–0 win over [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] on 27 April 1901 in the [[Western Football League|Western League]].{{sfn|Tarrant|Lindsay|2010|page=264}} Millwall relocated for the start of the 1901–02 season to a location near their second home, which became known as North Greenwich.{{sfn|Lindsay|1991|pages=32–33}} Their first game at North Greenwich was against [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] on 21 September 1901, which they lost 2–3. The Game was watched by 6,000 people.{{sfn|Tarrant|Lindsay|2010|page=266}} Coincidentally, the last game played on the Isle of Dogs on 8 October 1910 was against the same team, Portsmouth. This time Millwall won 3–1.{{sfn|Lindsay|1991|page=176}} Due to lack of expansion space in the [[Millwall]] area of East London, Millwall moved to [[South London]] in 1910 and into their ground, [[The Den (defunct stadium)|The Den]]. ==Attendances== The record attendance at North Greenwich was 16,285 in the [[FA Cup]], in a 1–0 win against [[Woolwich Arsenal F.C.|Woolwich Arsenal]] on 10 February 1909 in a Second round replay.{{sfn|Tarrant|Lindsay|2010|page=280}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ===Bibliography=== *{{Cite book |first=Richard |last=Lindsay |title=Millwall: A Complete Record, 1885–1991 | publisher=Breedon Books Publishing Co Ltd| year=1991| isbn=0-907969-94-1|ref=harv}} *{{Cite book |first1=Eddie |last1=Tarrant |first2=Richard| last2=Lindsay |title=Millwall: The Complete Record | publisher=DB Publishing | year=2010| isbn=1-85983-833-2|ref=harv}} {{Millwall F.C.}} [[Category:Millwall F.C.]] [[Category:Defunct football venues in England]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1901]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Use Australian English|date=January 2018}} {{More citations needed|date=July 2008}} A '''one percenter''' ('''1%er''') is a statistic kept in [[Australian rules football]], and relates to a variety of actions which benefit the team, but are infrequent or defensive.
==History== It has been standard for a long time for a coach to tell his team to "keep doing the one percenters," and this essentially meant that players should keep applying pressure on opponents, by doing the little extra efforts which make turnovers more likely. They have always been seen as the "little extra effort" which went unrewarded on the statistics, and they received the name "one percenter" to represent this. They may not individually affect the outcome of the game, but collectively they can, hence they are regarded as a percentage of the overall performance of the team. Coaches have always liked to see their teams put in the effort and get plenty of one percenters, and the captains and spiritual leaders of teams are most often skilful players with the most one percenters. At the beginning of the 21st century, one percenters were officially recognised as a statistic. In 2007, the [[AFL Army Award]] was struck to reward, among other defensive skills, one percenters.
==Definition== There are four actions which constitute a one percenter according to official [[Australian Football League|AFL]] statistics: knock-ons, spoils, smothers, and shepherds.
===Knock-ons=== A '''knock-on''' is using the hand, either clenched or open, to tap the ball to the advantage of a team-mate, without ever taking possession of the football (except out of the ruck). It has the same advantage as a quick handpass or kick, but is not recognised as a disposal because the player never has possession.
===Spoil=== A '''spoil''' is preventing an opposition player from taking clean possession of a pass from a team-mate. This is most usually done by punching the ball away from the contest. In the 2011 semi-final against [[Sydney Swans|Sydney]], [[Hawthorn Football Club|Hawthorn]] defender [[Joshua Gibson (footballer)|Josh Gibson]] compiled an AFL record 21 spoils.<ref>{{cite web|last=Macgugan|first=Mark|title=Hawk defenders have no fear|url=http://www.hawthornfc.com.au/news/2011-09-17/hawk-defenders-have-no-fear|accessdate=10 January 2013}}</ref>
===Smother=== [[File:Australian football smother.jpg|thumb|A player in red preparing to try and smother the kick from the player in blue]] A '''smother''' is the act of using the arms or body to get in the way of an opponent's kick, as it leaves the player's boot. A player who smothers the ball is generally seen diving across in front of the kicking player, hoping to trap the ball as it is kicked. Smothers sometimes lead to turn-overs, but not always.
===Shepherd=== {{main|Shepherding (Australian rules football)}} A '''shepherd''' is the legal act of preventing an opponent from obtaining the ball or tackling a team-mate.
==Other one percenters== There are other defensive efforts and supporting actions which are not statistically recognised as one percenters. However, when coaches refer to one percenters, these actions are often also considered.
===Chase=== A '''chase''' is the act of making a long pursuit behind an opponent who is running with and bouncing the ball, even if he never catches up and tackles his opponent. A chase puts pressure on the opponent to kick while running quickly and/or while unstable, decreasing the likely accuracy of the kick. Hence, coaches will consider a chase to be a one percenter.
===Hurry=== '''Hurrying''' (or corralling) an opponent is the act of putting them off balance without laying a tackle, while he is taking his kick or handpass. Like the chase, this increases the likelihood of a turnover, and is often considered to be a one percenter.
===Bump=== [[File:Bump womens football.jpg|thumbnail|150px|A strong and legal bump to gain possession of the ball.]]
:See [[Bump (football)]] A '''bump''' or '''hip and shoulder''' is the act of using the side of the body and running into an opponent with force - under some circumstances. The bump is a type of strong shepherd, but players can also legally bump their opponents out of the way as they run to collected the ball. A bump to an opponent is legal, provided the bump does not ride high and contact an opponent's head. A bump in the back is illegal under the "push in the back".
===Block=== A '''block''' or '''screen''' is a more subtle way to shepherd in a marking contest, and while it is often technically illegal, it will almost never be penalised. The most common way to block is to run between a leading forward and his pursuing opponent, slowing down the defender so that the forward will take his mark uncontested.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.iafc.com.au/g_checking.html Checking Skills - from the International Australian Football Council]
{{Australian rules football terminology}}

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox sports team | color1 = white | color2 = gray | logo = Riptide.PNG | pixels = 150px | founded = 2006 | league = [[American Basketball Association (21st century)|ABA]] | history = no games ever played | arena = | city = [[Portland, Oregon]] | colors = TBA | owner = [[Christopher Sears]] | coach = TBA | championships = 0 | titles = 0 | cheerleaders = | dancers = | mascot = }} The '''Oregon Riptide''' was the name chosen for an [[American Basketball Association (21st century)|American Basketball Association (ABA)]] franchise which was to be based in [[Portland, Oregon]]. In May, 2006, founding team owner, Jeremy "J" Brice, of [[Salem, Oregon|Salem]], had gained ABA approval, opened a front office in downtown Portland, and announced its staff.<ref name="ABA1">{{cite press release | title = Oregon Riptide announce web site and front office | publisher=American Basketball Association | date = May 4, 2006 | url = http://www.abalive.com/news/releases/?newsid=2006050406001 | accessdate =November 29, 2006}}</ref> A May 27 free agent camp was held to recruit an initial roster of players.<ref name="ABA2">{{cite press release | title = Oregon Riptide free agent camp crucial | publisher=American Basketball Association | date = May 8, 2006 | url = http://www.abalive.com/news/releases/?newsid=2006050806006 | accessdate =November 29, 2006}}</ref>
Brice arranged with [[Warner Pacific College]] for arena facilities for a summer youth basketball camp to be sponsored by the team, and for the competitive season to have begun in November, 2006.<ref name="pdxtrib1">{{cite news |last = Vondersmith |first = Jason |title = Basketball team owner's past could derail dream |publisher=[[Portland Tribune]] |date = July 13, 2006 |url = http://www.portlandtribune.com/news/story.php?story_id=115284969806224900 |accessdate =February 26, 2007}}</ref> He had even contracted with the Jupiter Hotel to house visiting team members.<ref name="ABA3">{{cite press release | title = Oregon Riptide partners with Jupiter Hotel | publisher=American Basketball Association | date = May 22, 2006 | url = http://www.abalive.com/news/releases/?newsid=2006052206001 | accessdate =November 29, 2006}}</ref>
Plans for the youth camp were quickly cancelled in July, 2006, following an article revealing that Brice, a Nevada native who had served as a high school and youth league coach, was a registered sex offender in both [[California]] and Oregon. As a result, he could not have unsupervised contact with girls under 18, except for his daughter. Warner Pacific, a Christian college affiliated with the conservative [[Church of God (Anderson)]], withdrew availability of their facilities.<ref name="pdxtrib1"/>
Brice sold the franchise to [[Christopher Sears]] less than a week later, telling a reporter for the ''Tribune,'' "I am no longer associated with the Riptide due to the negativity and black cloud over my name." The league approved the transfer, and Joe Newman, ABA CEO, stated that the team would still play in the 2006 season.<ref name="pdxtrib2">{{cite news | title = Sources say: Scandal-ridden Riptide ownership changes hands | publisher=Portland Tribune | date = July 18, 2006 | url = http://www.portlandtribune.com/sports/story.php?story_id=115319174037799200 | accessdate =February 26, 2007}}</ref> When the ABA season started in November 2006, however, the Oregon Riptide was not on the schedule.
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.abalive.com/ American Basketball Association (ABA) official website]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}} {{Use British English|date=July 2011}} '''Prince's Cricket Ground''' in [[Chelsea, London]] was a [[cricket]] ground, created by the brothers George and James Prince as part of the [[Prince's Club]], on which 37 [[first-class cricket|first-class]] matches were played between 1872 and 1878. The ground was built on in 1883. The boundaries of the site, laid out on the former Cattleugh's nursery gardens, are marked by Cadogan Square West, [[Milner Street]], Lennox Gardens Mews, [[Walton Street, London|Walton Street]] and Pont Street.<ref>Not to be confused with the 18th century Brighton [[Prince of Wales Ground]].</ref>
The 1872 edition of ''[[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack]]'' described the ground as 'grand and quick and one of the finest playing grounds in England'.<ref name='LPGT'>{{cite web|title=Lennox Gardens|url=http://londongardensonline.org.uk/gardens-online-record.php?ID=KAC094|work=London Gardens Online - Lennox Gardens|publisher=London Parks & Gardens Trust|accessdate=6 November 2018}}</ref>
The first match played on the ground was Household Brigade v. Lords and Commons on 3 June 1871.<ref name=illustrated>{{cite journal|title=Old Prince's Club|journal=[[The Illustrated Sporting and Dramatic News]]|date=21 September 1918|volume=90|issue=2349|pages=82–83|url=http://www.illustratedfirstworldwar.com/item/old-princes-club-bpc000004_19180921_01_0028/#}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Prince's Cricket Club|url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000181/18710605/027/0004|work=Sheffield and Rotherham Independent|publisher=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|date=5 June 1871|page=4|subscription=y}}</ref>
[[Middlesex County Cricket Club]] used the ground between 1872 and 1876 and played their first match on 23–25 May 1872 against Yorkshire. The ground was also used by [[South of England cricket team|South of England]] and by Gentlemen of the South. Several [[Gentlemen v Players]] fixtures were also played there, the first taking place in July 1873. In 1878, the [[Australian cricket team in England and North America in 1878|touring Australians]] played two matches on the ground: Gentlemen of England v Australians and Players v Australians (the last first-class match held on the ground, scheduled for 11 September to 13 September but finished in two days).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Lazenby|first1=John|title=The strangers who came home : the first Australian cricket tour of England, 1878|date=2013|publisher=Bloomsbury|location=London|isbn=978-1408842874|pages=114–121}}</ref> The increasing acquisition of portions of the site for building development, made possible by 'The Cadogan and Hans Place Improvement Act of 1874', discouraged its further use.
The former first-class cricketer [[Thomas Box]] was employed as an attendant at the ground. On 12 July 1876, during the Middlesex v Nottinghamshire match, he collapsed. He died three hours later.<ref>[http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/ci/content/player/9916.html Cricinfo piece on Tom Box]</ref>
The site was also used for [[lawn tennis]], [[badminton]] and other games. A permanent [[roller skating]] rink was also added.<ref>[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.asp?compid=45224 Chelsea: Cremorne Gardens, ''Old and New London: Volume 5'', 1878, pp 84-100.]</ref>
== Ground records in first-class matches == *'''Highest total:''' 612 Oxford University v Middlesex 1876 (at the time, the highest total ever made in a first-class match) *'''Lowest total:''' 47 Middlesex v Oxford University 1874 *'''Highest individual score:''' 261 [[W.G. Grace]] South of England v North of England 1877 *'''Best bowling:''' 8-31 [[Fred Morley]] Players of the North v Gentlemen of the South 1875 *'''Highest partnership''' 281 (for the 2nd wicket) W.G. Grace & [[Montagu Cotterill|J.M. Cotterill]] South of England v North of England 1877
== References == {{reflist}}
== Sources == *[http://www.espncricinfo.com/england/content/ground/57134.html Cricinfo: Prince's Cricket Ground] *[[Simon Rae]], ''W.G. Grace: A Life'', 1998, {{ISBN|978-0-571-17855-1}}.

{{Infobox horseraces |class = Group 3 |horse race = Prix de Royaumont |image = |caption = |location = [[Chantilly Racecourse]]
[[Chantilly, Oise|Chantilly]], [[France]] |inaugurated = 1883 |race type = [[Flat racing|Flat]] / [[Thoroughbred]] |website = [http://www.france-galop.com/All-the-races.233+M52087573ab0.0.html?&course_id=1589&no_cache=1&numero_id=127 france-galop.com] |distance = 2,400 metres (1½ miles) |surface = Turf |track = Right-handed |qualification = Three-year-old [[Filly|fillies]]
excluding Group winners |weight = 57 [[Kilogram|kg]] |purse = [[Euro|€]]80,000 ''(2015)''
'''1st:''' €40,000 |bonuses = }} The '''Prix de Royaumont''' is a [[Conditions races|Group 3]] [[Flat racing|flat]] [[Horse racing|horse race]] in [[France]] open to three-year-old [[thoroughbred]] [[Filly|fillies]]. It is run at [[Chantilly Racecourse|Chantilly]] over a distance of 2,400 metres (about 1½ miles), and it is scheduled to take place each year in late May or early June. ==History== The event is named after [[Royaumont Abbey]], an abbey located 12 km from Chantilly. The race was established in 1883, and it was originally contested over 2,100 metres. It was initially reserved for fillies considered below the standard required for the [[Prix de Diane]], which used to be run on the same day. The Prix de Royaumont was abandoned throughout World War I, with no running from 1915 to 1918. The first two post-war editions were staged at [[Longchamp Racecourse|Longchamp]]. The race was cancelled once during World War II, in 1940. It was held at Longchamp in 1941 and 1942, and at [[Tremblay Park|Le Tremblay]] with a distance of 2,150 metres in 1943 and 1944. It was contested at Longchamp for the following three years, and it returned to Chantilly in 1948. The Prix de Royaumont was not run in 1975 because of a strike by stable lads. A new schedule was introduced in 1978, and the race was moved to a date earlier than that of the Prix de Diane. The event was staged at Longchamp from 1987 to 1990, and it was transferred to [[Saint-Cloud Racecourse|Saint-Cloud]] in 1991. Its distance was extended to 2,400 metres in 1992, and it continued to take place at Saint-Cloud until 1996. The race's only subsequent departure from Chantilly was in 2001, when it was run at Saint-Cloud. The Prix de Royaumont is now held on the same day as the [[Prix du Jockey Club]]. ==Records==
'''Leading [[jockey]] (4 wins):''' * F. Crickmere – ''Stresa (1883), Estelle (1886), Fatuite (1890), Amazone (1891)'' * [[Charles Semblat]] – ''Tetratela (1924), Raflade (1926), Samphire (1927), Finlandaise (1935)'' * Fernand Rochetti – ''L'Abbesse de Menin (1930), Pereire (1939), Picardie (1947), Seduction (1948, dead-heat)'' * Jean Deforge – ''All Risk (1955), Chaleureuse (1962), Partisane (1963), Dreida (1964)'' * [[Yves Saint-Martin]] – ''Marie Jolie (1960), Bubunia (1966), Casaque Grise (1967), Waya (1977)'' * [[Dominique Boeuf]] – ''Miss Alleged (1990), Villandry (1991), Side Saddle (1999), Volga (2001)'' * [[Christophe Soumillon]] - ''Diasilixa (2003), Shawanda (2005), Sub Rose (2008), Kataniya (2015)'' ---- '''Leading [[Horse trainer|trainer]] (11 wins):''' * [[André Fabre]] – ''Galla Placidia (1985), Villandry (1991), Berceau (1992), Apogee (1993), Genovefa (1995), Legend Maker (1997), Dance Routine (2002), Diasilixa (2003), Minatlya (2006), Legerete (2007), Savanne (2014)'' ---- '''Leading owner (7 wins):''' * Jean Prat – ''Marjolaine (1893), Cabane (1908), Musique (1921), Raflade (1926), Sesia (1931), Relique (1933), Marphise (1938)''

{{unreferenced|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox football club| | clubname = Raja de Beni Mellal| | image = | fullname = Raja Beni Mellal| | nickname = ''Rajae Attarikh''| | founded = 1956| | ground = Stade d'honneur de Beni Mellal| | capacity = 15,000| | chairman = Abdessadek Boudal | manager = Reda Hakam | league = {{Flagicon|Morocco}} [[Botola 2]] | pattern_la1=_rbm1| pattern_b1=_rbm1| pattern_ra1=_rbm1| pattern_sh1=_rbm1| pattern_so1=_rbm1 | leftarm1= 007700| body1= 007700| rightarm1= 007700| shorts1= 007700| socks1= 007700| pattern_la2=_rbm2 | pattern_b2=_rbm2 | pattern_ra2=_rbm2 | pattern_sh2=_rbm2 | pattern_so2=_rbm2 | leftarm2=ffffff| body2=ffffff| rightarm2=ffffff| shorts2=ffffff| socks2=ffffff| pattern_la3=_rbm3| pattern_b3=_rbm3| pattern_ra3=_rbm3 | pattern_sh3=_rbm3| pattern_so3=_rbm3| leftarm3= 000000| body3= 000000| rightarm3= 000000| shorts3= 000000| socks3= 000000| }}
'''Raja Beni Mellal''' is a [[Morocco|Moroccan]] [[Association football|football]] [[Club (organization)|club]] currently playing in the second division [[Elite 2]]. The club was founded in 1956 and is located in the town of [[Beni Mellal]].
==History==
Raja Beni Mellal was founded in 1956 by Monsieur Abdellatif Mesfioui after the alliance of a set of clubs of the city of [[Beni Mellal]] they included the '''Ittihad Al Mellali''' et '''La Mouloudia'''.
Abdellatif Mesfioui was the first president of the club following the merger between the Ittihad and Mouloudia. The club businesses still have the final of the '''Champions Cup Maghreb''' against [[Club Africain]]. Best Presidents of the club's history to date were Lhaj Jilali Lasri (1973-1974 and 1974-1975) and his son Lhaj Abdelwahed Lasri (2010-2011 and 2011-2012) where during their activity there have been the best four seasons in the history of Raja Beni Mellal.
==Honours==
*'''[[Maghreb Champions Cup]]''' **Runner-up: 1975 *'''[[Botola|Moroccan Championship]]''' '''(1)''' **Champion: 1974
==External links== *[Club logo: http://ma.news80.com/wp-content/uploads/HLIC/983d27133f977ea8b861c8c8cf8687c6.png]
